It has the hype of S1, the intense mystery of S2, and the interesting political intrigue of S3A (in the latter episodes mind you) - and then adds a layer of its own. Does it live up to the hype? The ridiculously high score given by the users of MAL, contrasting to the other seasons of AoT? Yes. Story - 10 Again, this is what the rest of the series has been building up to. Cruel fates are ... met by friends and foes alike; emotional turmoil runs rampant; hidden truths are unveiled; and mindblowing moments are everywhere. The writing is stellar. See, build-up has to payoff in order for the story to work, otherwise it isn’t even build-up - because if the culmination of everything isn’t satisfying, the series itself isn’t satisfying. This season delivers on everything it has presented to you thus far. The basement isn’t some last-episode-of-the-series, far off plot point anymore, it’s a main focus now. The Colossal Titan is no longer some “big baddie” you see once in a while who then runs off, as this is the ultimate battle with him. Mindgames and in-depth battle tactics are everywhere. How major players are defeated simply makes sense - and the characters use what they already have at their disposal to achieve their goal. This arc has the most big-name deaths, not just side character deaths - and yes, plot armor is still there, but it mostly makes sense as to why a certain character survived (except for one character - a villain, though). The payoff near the end of the season is unparalleled. I don’t want to go in-depth because of spoilers, but the world of Attack on Titan is expanded beautifully. You will, without a doubt, have to rewatch certain episodes to make sure you got the full gist of everything, because new information will hit you like a brick, but it all just makes sense. The basement lives up to the hype. It will destroy your mind. The pacing is stellar, with the 8 out of the 10 episodes adapting 2 chapters of the manga, and the other two episodes not feeling too dragged out. Heartfelt moments are executed brilliantly. Character arcs come to a satisfying close as new ones begin, and with the more emotional moments, tears will flow. Negatives, as far as story goes, would have to be a certain villain’s frustrating plot armor and the possibility of being left completely confused after an information-heavy episode. Art - 9 There is a battle sequence that took about a month to animate, and it is one of the most jaw-dropping moments of the series. I really hope WIT stays with Attack on Titan, because they are perfect for this series. The backgrounds, especially in the latter episodes, are astonishingly breathtaking; scenes without said backgrounds would not be nearly as hard-hitting. However, it is not entirely perfect, which is why it receives a 9 rather than a 10: it is inconsistent. Even within the best-animated episodes are a few wonky-looking animations, lazy hair movements, and ODM sequences that just feel… off. It’s only on occasion and is more prevalent in episodes 2-5, getting better as it goes along. Along with that is the dreaded CGI Colossal Titan. It can look downright atrocious at times. Other times, it looks fine, and when it is properly animated in 2D, it looks great. But, again, the pros vastly outweigh the cons in this area, and it’s still an upgrade from the latter half of season 2 when every other shot was a still. Sound - 10 Sawano is a genius. Every single one of his OSTs is a banger. From melancholy pieces for the sad moments to thrilling pieces for the hype moments, the Attack on Titan soundtrack remains one of the greatest; and the new tracks created for this season are no different. The sheer emotion one can feel from a track he created is simply amazing. Voice acting is superb, well, the Japanese VAs anyway. I remember one scene that chose a haunting silence instead of a soundtrack coupled with amazing voice acting, making for some very tense moments that fill you with goosebumps. Character - 10 One of the biggest complaints from S1 is now completely gone. This area has progressively gotten better over the series, and arcs that began long ago come to a conclusion in this season. Characters previously thought to be one-note throwaways are now complex human beings that see things differently from everybody else. The main protagonist, Eren, who was criticized for being a cliche screaming “I want to achieve X” MC is now one of the most well-written characters in the series. Just like the story built up to this season, character arcs that have been built up also come to a conclusion, whether it be ending with their death or beginning to head in a new direction. Enjoyment - 10 Combining the hype moments, the jaw-dropping reveals, and the tearjerkers, this season is a banger. It is the bangiest of bangers. How does one combine every possible amazing thing an anime can do, into one anime? I don’t know, ask Isayama and WIT. But this season achieves something truly great, making for one of the most enjoyable experiences you’ll ever have. Overall - 10 Did you watch S1 and drop it? Understandable, I guess. S1 was nothing special - it was GOOD, but compared to this… I don’t want to insult S1, but this is just in another league entirely. Watch it. Watch this season and then rewatch to pick up on all of the hints and foreshadowing for the reveals this season has to offer. Watch Attack on Titan.

SnK Season 3 (Part 2) is the result of an anime that has always shined brightly while unable to fully hide various flaws, becoming polished to absolute perfection. The story is fast-paced and is heavy on the action, making up for where it lacked in Part 1. The sense of foreboding in episode 1 is palpable. The early episodes really do a great job of reinforcing your hatred for the villains; I didn't think it was possible to hate the trio of traitors any more than I already did, but a harrowing flashback in episode 3 actually achieves this! The Beast titan is as detestable, smug, ... and ugly as ever. The relentless battle of the first half is equal parts thrilling and devastating. Erwin's charge is a moment showcasing the anime's emotional core: desperate hope in the face of insurmountable odds. And episode 6 is perhaps my favourite episode in all of SnK so far...the choice presented feels absolutely gut-wrenching for all involved, and I think the episode is done just perfectly. The remaining episodes are the most satisfying of the whole series and finally begin to unravel the mysteries of the SnK world, incorporating a pretty harrowing story in flashback form. It's been a long time coming, and it's well worth the wait. The characterisation has only continued to get stronger from season to season. In Part 2 the greatest standout to me is Armin, a boy who has been consistently proving himself as a smart and valuable ally throughout SnK but who had remained a little underrated by his peers, fully blossoms in this season and it's beautiful to watch. Erwin and Levi shine brightly as well. My opinion on the sound and the art is unchanged from previous seasons: the music is fine. The animation is outstandingly brilliant. Kudos. Overall, I enjoyed Part 3 the most of any season to date. Previous seasons have always been strong but have consistently had setbacks too; whereas I think Part 3 really nails every element. The action, the pacing, the significant emotional gut-punching, the exposition, the final scenes...this anime is a joy to watch, and makes me giddy with anticipation for the final season.

Building on twelve full episodes of setup, the second half of Attack on Titan's third season sees us return to the place that started it all, as the Survey Corps enter the city of Shiganshina, where they hope to finally access Grisha Yeager's basement and accede to his request to carry on his mission and to unravel the great secrets of their world. In the process, the series transforms itself into a completely different tale and sets the stage to what will undoubtedly be an amazing final season. After years of lovingly recreating mangaka Hajime Isayama's artwork, WIT Studio surpasses itself and delivers some of the ... greatest action scenes in the medium, perfectly capturing the large yet intimate scale of Titan battles. Particular praise has to go to the final confrontation with the Beast Titan, which is crafted with so much love and passion from the studio and the cast that it almost defies comprehension. Speaking of the voice cast, they all rise to the occasion in their finest collective effort yet. Yuki Kaji as Eren continues to deliver an impossibly passionate performance that proves his undying committment to the character. But the highlight of the season has to be Daisuke Ono as Erwin Smith, who truly shines this season and cements his place in the pantheon of legendary shounen characters. Sadly the same cannot be said of the entire cast. Mikasa continues to get shafted incredibly hard by Isayama, as by this point she is nothing but an extension of Eren's character, which especially stings this season now that other major cast members such as Erwin, Armin and Levi have gotten their own moments in the spotlight. And finally, special mention must go to Hange, who is absolutely precious. While they are not the best character in the series, she is incredibly enjoyable and unique. The fact that she and the other senior members of the Resistance (Levi, Zachary, etc.) aren't treated as saints and are given moral complexity only adds to this enjoyment. One of the best mystery stories I've ever experienced, Part 2 doubles as a great exploration of how legacies of hatred are passed down from one generation to the next, and how we are all nothing but products of much larger systems of oppression that we must desperately fight against throughout our entire lives, lest they repeat themselves for eternity. The stage is now set for a game-changing fourth and final season, and I could not be more hopeful.

attack on titan Season 3 Part 2 is one of the best shonen arcs i have ever seen , even after s 4 part 1  return of shiganshina still stands as a peak of attack on titan (for now) ,  every episode of this arc was 9-10/10 , and its crazy that we had this episodes: "Perfect Game" ,"Hero" , "Midnight Sun" , "The Basement"  and " That Day"  back to back , bothi in storywise and actionwise this season was perfect it had wonderfull plot execution, even tho animation wasnt 1st season lvl ,because of the tight schedule ,its still ... had top noch sakuga moments . so overly its   a 9.5-10/10 arc for me

The first 5 eps is great about emotions, the second 5 eps is logical and explanatory. It can be said that part 2 of season 3 is a special case, I can divide these 10 eps into two parts. Part 1: Battle of Shiganshina Indeed this is what I expect from AOT. Both season 2 and part 1 of season 3, at the climax, I still feel those battles have not reached the level of excitement as season 1, but here things are different. The battle with the Beast Titan at Shiganshina was so dramatic, thrilling every second and made me unable to take my eyes off the ... screen. The fighting scenes between survey corps and titans are not only good in terms of action but also in terms of war tactics. The characters all have their own moments. There are some very interesting characters, so their ending makes me feel sad. I was expecting a more epic ending for those characters. The music is really the bright spot, I'm always immersed in the atmosphere of the story very quickly. After the battle ended, I was waiting for the next eps to explode, so I had expectations. Part 2: Explanations for the Mysteries If someone was waiting for the tunes of the final episodes to be as dramatic as the battle at Shiganshina, they'd be a bit disappointed. This stage describes the aftermath of the war and the secrets are revealed. It can be said that the tempo of these eps is slower and softer. The story of the mystery of the titans is explained quite reasonably, especially with the "important key" details connected to the previous seasons, I really like these two points. However, everything is too exciting in the first eps, so when the story of the other world is described, everything becomes new and the viewer will have to try to remember new words, new concepts, and accidentally lost the drama inherent in the first eps. After all, the past is only for explaining the question. The flashbacks are the whole episode length reveal the mysteries, and I have said in the previous reviews, the mystery is revealed, the attractiveness is only at a ratio of 50/50. I have a lot of respect for the stories about titan that the author tried to bring to explain the world of AOT. But no matter how hard I try, the appeal of this answer cannot be maintained at the level of the eps talk about the current battle - Shiganshina. In particular, although the supporting characters and main characters are impressive to some extent, the only thing missing from this season is the interaction between the characters, I mean the love between them. This has not yet been shown convincingly. The characters behave too mechanically, talking only about plans, heroism, and battles, instead of gestures of intimacy or concern for one another. The part where Eren-Historia interacts in the field is a short romance, it's too little compared to the number of young boys and girls in the story. And in the end, the main character is put into a sluggish, miserable mood, no longer connected with people. Right now, love is the only thing that brings the character to good, but this is inherently rare from the beginning. Art is not the highlight, compared to season 1. The ending brings many facts, many strange concepts about war, between one race and another, instead of bringing the viewer into a state of emotional satisfaction. If anyone is looking forward to a complicated story, many questions want to be answered, here are 10 eps worth enjoying. If anyone just wants to see exciting battles, heroic characters, they will prefer the first 5 eps.

Attack on Titan Season 3 Part 2 is the genuine high point for the series. In a surprising turn, there isn't a whole lot I dislike about this season. The art direction, acting, music, sound and sequences are start-to-finish perfect. The only gripes I have with this season is the introduction of elements that were not previously established (you'll know when you see them.) The lack of foreshadowing for these elements, or at least establishing them prior, which is possible because the manga was far past this area when the anime was being made. Regardless, these elements are only momentarily jarring and overall, this Season ... is the best sequence of Attack on Titan we ever got.

Attack on Titans has got to be one of the best anime series that I have ever seen. Since the beginning, the series has created an exponential amount of hype and this season has kept up with that expectation. This section was one of the most hyped chunks of episodes I have ever seen. Every single episode left me on the edge of my seat and wanting more. It killed me to patiently wait every week for the next episode to air. Everything that the series has offered so far has been phenomenal: from the incredible world-building, the developments of the character's personalities, the animation ... direction, to the incredible original soundtrack. As someone who has read the manga for this part of the series, I can say that the anime stayed loyal to the original source material. I applaud WIT studios for their amazing work on the animation! You can definitely tell that they went all out this season and that took an incredible amount of care into their work. The soundtrack has got to be one of the best soundtracks that I have ever heard in an anime. The immense hype I get from listening to “ətˈæk 0N tάɪtn” is unreal! Finally, we see that our characters have grown so much from their season 1 counterparts. Every action and event that has occurred in the previous season has changed our characters and it is shown through their actions and decisions. I am very excited to see where the story will continue from here, can not wait for season four: the final season to begin airing and watch this story coming to its end.

This is easily my favorite part of AOT. I don’t have much to say about it other than that it’s perfect. This season alone is a reason why you should watch AOT. A lot of the characters including Armin, Erwin, Levi, Zeke, and even Jean show tremendous development and have some pretty awesome moments. It’s an action packed 10 episodes and most certainly has the best arc (imo) up to this point. The Return to Shiganshina is what all viewers waited for and I would hate to hear that anyone was disappointed about it. Biased or unbiased, I believe this season is a 10/10. It ... connects the plot perfectly as viewers begin to see the masterpiece before them.

THIS, this is where Attack on Titan reached masterpiece for me. The show finally crossed the line of amazing thrill and shocking moments to "investing". In an arc filled with big battle scenes, the best episodes were deeply psychological. I enjoy the battle strategies of this arc, so much big brain energy on all sides. I love the theme of owning up to one decision with no regrets that the show explored, each choice revealed each character's essence. How in a war, you will end up losing something, but choosing what to lose is also a big part of survival. It really elevate the conflict ... in each scene. The arc also finally provide us the satisfaction of learning the "truth" and the consequences of obtaining it. Sometimes that might not you free, and you can feel the weight of that on the characters. You know the world change from this point forward, and it just bring so much excitement and dread. Top 3 characters this season: Eren (The hell this boy has been through. Eren's forever change by the truth, with his whole believe system being stripped down.), Hanji (She's been one of my favorite characters on the show as an advocate for progress, but she also hold the scout together emotionally here.), Floch (Probably controversial yet I think he adds so much depth to AOT. We've only seen the story from our main cast POV and have our bias, but as an outsider, he was the one affected by their choices without being able to choose.)

As 2019 comes to a close and after viewing the series that this Fall had to offer, I feel more and more confident that this year's season of Attack on Titan was the best anime TV show of the year. This season WIT Studios has fixed AoT's horrendous pacing problem, giving us non-stop, back-to-back violence, drama, horrid spectacle, and most importantly Sawano. In its current state it is the show that fanboys and fangirls made the series out to be. I'm not sure if it was because of where the series ended up in the manga or because WIT had like 5 years to make 2 ... half seasons, but I guess we'll see in retrospect when season 4 gets picked up by a new studio? IDK, but I'd say if you haven't touched the series yet; get through the first 2 seasons and get treated by this one.

if u want a quick review , here it is for u story from the start until the end make the top scenes in the anime history .. the hidden points is well known in story >> boldness, courage, sacrifice and redemption, the principle of freedom and the rejection of racism, all of those add another dimension in the plot art and character convenient ... they serve the anime story sound best ost ever from season 1 until the end Enjoyment How can you not enjoy a series where each episode expands its plot as characters get developed and gets more build up that will lead into a really great episode? Attack on titan isn't the kind of anime to waste it's time on filler episodes. It never ever had an episode which never progressed the story. I never felt bored watching it nor rewatching it and nor will i ever be to sum up , stop seeing review and go watch the best anime ever

What a twist! Attack on titan was pretty hype, then it died down a bit, third season was fine, but this final part sure kicks it up a notch! What I loved the most, in no particular order: - The music, but that's always been a strong point. - Characters making logical decisions! :o There's still a lot of crazy stuff and plot convenience like every anime, but in this case there are several points where you expect an anime trope, but instead, the characters act rationally, quickly, and without mercy. Good! - Beautiful choreography! - Consequences for actions taken! I wish more characters had died as a result of their ... actions, but the fact that some did is a good step in the right direction. - Good animation! Way good in fact! - Aaand finally, a bunch of questions are getting answered, the BBG gets introduced (maybe?), and it feels like the plot is going somewhere! All in all, I felt very satisfied after viewing this season, which sets up some neat things, delves into some backstory, has powerful and logical action scenes, some emotional scenes, and a good send-off. If you've been sticking with AoT this long, definitely watch it!

Story It was as if the previous seasons was just the development needed for a big payoff during this season, The pacing is a lot better this time around. Exposition and action happen more frequently to keep you entertained. The lore is explored much more throughly in this part than in the other parts. The lore is deep, but not hard to understand or interpret. Plenty of edge of your seats moments as well. Easily the best season thus far Art Great artwork and animation especially during battles Sound Better than the first part of season 3, but not super memorable Character Way more development this time around than in the previous ... seasons. Previous chracters are given way more depth and backstory. Enjoyment This is peak attack on titan and easily the best season. A wonderful watch Overall If you liked the previous seasons, you would probably love this season

This review is for *both* the first and second half's of season 3. I find it hard to believe that we're nearing the end of this amazing series. Attack on Titan has been an anime that I've been following since it's debut back in 2013, and it's been a wild ride since then. First season was immensely popular and enthralling, while the second left more to be desired. However, after finishing this season, and finally putting the puzzle pieces together, I'm sure that this season is by far the most emotionally compelling yet. And I cannot stress this enough, but this season in particular showed ... some of the best character development among all three so far, specifically in Eren. To conclude this short review, I find it hard to not give this season a 10/10. However with the fourth season coming next year, I'm sure that one will hit those numbers. This season also had some amazing sound design and epic openers. Art-style is still kicking too. All in all though, I HIGHLY recommend you giving this a watch if you're even slightly intrigued with AOT at all (If there's one thing however, that they could have done better, it's not splitting S3 into two parts).

the perfect conclusion to everything the series has been building to so far. elements of story and world and character introduced as early as season 1 all tie together in a brilliant display of multilinear storytelling prowess. just when i thought there couldn't be any more secrets to unveil, world-shattering revelations that have been hinted at the entire series are revealed. a reveal so hyped-up by the show as the Jaeger basement could have easily been underwhelming, but instead it pushes the show forward with more momentum ever. I have a hard time believing the final season can even equal or top what has come ... before, but I can certainly hope.

You want to know the truth so bad but is it really worth it? Will knowing it fulfill your desire of destroying the unknown instead of living in ignorance? The 3rd season of Shingeki no Kyojin had me in a chokehold. I was gasping for air throughout every episode. Yearning for the truth to be revealed but as soon as I knew what was going on, it's like it's not worth knowing it anymore. Just like Eren, Mikasa and Armin were saying : "Will it bring back the old days?" And the answer is obviously, no. Beyond the fact that the plot is incredibly well written, ... I still think that there were moments where we could have turned the situation around (for example when the choice of revival was made, why not split the liquid and revive both since as seen before, Historia's father only had a small sip of it.) Grisha Jaeger... What a man. I'm at loss of words and can't wait to see how Eren will change from all the memories he'll live. Now the soundtrack does its job perfectly but I do think the openings are... Good. I know it's almost as if there's no flaw but, there really almost isn't. The art is what I appreciate the most though. The shading, the colors, the line art... Everything is so well thought on each frame that I'm left speechless (except for the colossal titan... that CGI didn't age well but honestly it's not that bad, just not as perfect as the rest.) I can't say I'm happy about the loss we experienced during this season but, I'm pleased that one character finally brought up the darkest side of humanity which we rarely see THIS strong. When all we see are brave soldiers that may doubt themselves here and there, we got to stay in touch with how surreal everything is. We need a reminder that, the protagonists are human beings facing such a terrifying situation. And this season does the job well. Just to add a bit more to how the story evolves, I think it was very fast but again this is pretty much how SNK works so... The fact that we can't digest anything and just have to live through it all is a "good" thing to me. It's like we're one of the characters. Though I do think that the truth should have been made clearer because it's pretty messy. And because of that, some points aren't getting across us, so please watch multiple times if needed. Was it a good season? Of course. Would I go through it again? Yeah, I'm into emotional rollercoasters. Recommend? OBVIOUSLY!

I think the entirety of season 3 (Pt.1 & Pt.2) was my favorite season. Like any other show, season 3 of Shingeki no Kyojin had its flaws, but overall it was really good. The animation was beautiful, the way you could tell the characters had gotten older was amazing. The plot was great, at this point it was no longer about fighting Titans, but discovering the truth. The action was great, throughout the entirety of season three there was a good balance between combat and emotional scenes, none of the times getting you bored. Several unexpected plot twists. The thing I love about all seasons of ... snk, is that the majority of characters, whether or not they get killed off, have importance besides backing up the protagonist. Like Ymir, even if they didn’t show her much, they still showed her past and her relationships, making us see how Great of a character she was. 10/10 would recommend.

I just dont know what to say . People who know me(so nobody of you huh)know that im not a BIG fan of AOt/SNK(i gave season 1-3 only 8/10) ... BUT THIS! THIS!!! every week feels like half a month now because i just want to finally see the next Episode XD Now the Review: I would really give this an 11/10 if i could.After the first 3 Episodes i said "oh hey why is this 9,.. rated?!But then i realised that this season will make History! Tons of new Twists and finally some Backround Information about the Titans omg!Im already hyped af for Season 4 ! Story:10 I dont really have to say anything here.Everything i could write here would be a huge Spoiler for the Retards that still not started this Season yet(i mean for real 260.000 members?where are all the People?) Art:9 The Art is high Quality af but i got bored of Erens ugly Face after 3 Seasons :))) Animations and Opening/Ending are smooth af too! Sound:10 One of the best Opening Songs ever and the Ending is so satisfying! I never cared about the Backround Soundtrack in the Anime so i cant say something about this! Character:9 Eren is too generic(still) Mikasa is annoying af without Levi the Characters would be 7/10 for real now) Enjoyment:10 Every Episode feels like just 10 minutes XD seems like i enjoy it kinda too much. Overall:10 One of the best things ever made! Thanks Wit Studio for making my Week a bit better!!

English is not my native language, so if you find some mistakes im sorry in advance. My review will contain minor spoilers, but i just feel the need to expose my opinion about this anime, because is just a master piece. Ive watched hundreds of animes in the last decade. There are out there many good animes, but trust me: NOTHING like this season of Shingeki no Kyojin. If you never watched this series, Stop reading and GO WATCH. The anime as a whole is pretty damn good, but this season its a MASTER PIECE, i repeat. Its the ectasy of the series , all the mistery ... and tension you have been building this past years are all in big BANGGGGG mod, exploding in your face, again and again and again and you are just WOW , hits you in the face and all makes sense now ( i dont read Mangas). The history is just amazing, the characters some of them you love and they die, bad guys , good guys they are all GREAT, you cheer for the good to win 90% of the time, but even the "bad guys" ( because good and evil in this anime gets a bit complicated, they have all their own reasons to do things, they all do what they believe is right) you get attached to all of them, they all have their emotions, their feelings, their reasons! And sometimes you find yourself lost on whos side you are at. The animation ive never seen ANYTHING LIKE THIS BEFORE, the colossal titan gets a bit clumsy, thats the only NO NO NO this season, but the overall is soo good that you say fak the colossal titan and YES YES YES! Music really gets you in the mood, amazing soundtrack. Enjoyment? Fak me. You are at your fakin seat like " when is this dude dying? When is that girl dying, or you are like YEAH!!! and then in one second: NOOOOO!!" man, you never know. The tension, the drama, it just kicks your ass. And its revelation after revelation, throwbacks that explain what you have been missing all along , they know how to do things. The speed of the anime is just perfect. No Fillers, no bullshits, like lets make money and money NARUTO Style for example or lets ruin the rest of the series "premature ejaculation style pace" like the second part of Deathnote, its just perfectly paced. OVERALL: 11 out of 10 it just blows your fakin mind. WATCH THIS SHITT, bye.

To put it quickly, this is the greatest anime I have ever seen in the fifteen I have been watching anime. The music. The animation. The art. The STORY. All amazing and top tier in quality. If you haven't seen this yet, then I strongly recommend you start it immediately. The intricacies of the plot are unlike anything I have ever watched. Just when you think you know what will happen next, the story completely throws you for a loop. You will seldom guess what's going to happen next, and that is truly a blessing after you've seen ever anime trope under the sun. Shingeki no ... Kyojin is a masterpiece that will set the standard for animes for years to come

Shingeki no Kyojin started catching many people with that interesting concept of giants, walls and brave young people. Even in the first episodes, it started surprising everyone. The plot was giving a hint that it was not just another anime. I watch anime since I was four years old and my ''top 5'' was very safe until I met SNK. But now, guys, the thing just got serious. At this point, in season 3 part 2, the world that was built so far is showing that it deserves not only a place in the top 5, but in the top 1. Everybody knows that the ... drawing and the OST are awesome, they always were, but the plot is getting to levels that I couldn't even imagine that an anime could. If you're reading this, WATCH SHINGEKI NO KYOJIN. I began season 3 part 2 already with this feeling, and as I finished it, I am sure that what the plot is preparing is something that will surprise us again. That's what this show always do. But this time, at the final season, if they do it right, SNK can become the greatest of all time. I am not a newbie, I have watched almost everything that people claimed to be the best. And I have a lot of prejudice with SNK. I will keep the 10/10 to sound and art, because I don't think they got better, it was always perfect. However, they seem better now because the PLOT is getting to absurd levels and that "marriage" can get beyond the 10. No more words. Watch this. Let's wait for the final season and hope they finish it with the necessary effort that this Masterpiece deserve. Only a tragedy could ruin this.

The review as a whole will contain spoilers for the previous seasons. I usually try to avoid spoilers, but this time, the problems are so directly related to the story that I have to address some of the plot elements. Those that have seen the previous parts of the show are safe for now. I will give a warning until I get to the spoilers for Season 3 Part 2. I actually loved the beginning of S3P2. The first six episodes, for me, were as good as the show has gotten since season 1. We are finally taking back Wall Maria. We will finally get to ... know the mystery of the cellar. We get the hyped up confrontation with the Armored and Colossal Titans - the one's that started it all. And the ruined district of Shiganshina is the perfect venue for this climactic confrontation. Seeing it again felt really cathartic. During the previous chapters, I almost forgot how satisfying it can be to be dealing with something that has been properly built up and not just hastily thrown at the wall with the hopes of it sticking. The battle of Shiganshina has a lot of great things going on. Bunch of great heroic moments and lots of incredibly over the top, brutal, action. The beast titan is hurling boulders baseball pitcher style. The Colossal Titan can cause something akin to a nuclear explosion upon transforming now. Much of it is stupid, but it's stupid in the most entertaining way possible. We get epic heroic speeches. Moments of sacrifice. Couple of anticlimactic deaths too, to remind us that it's not all roses and heroism on the battlefield. Very Attack on Titan. The entire injector dilemma was a brilliant and tense sequence. It was so good that I find it difficult to accept that it emerged from the same mind that came up with the atrocious Reiss family story and thought it wouldn't damage the setting. In a vacuum, the battle of Shiganshina is a lot fun. What drags it down, is that it is constantly climbing uphill after what the previous chapters did to the story as a whole. But over all, I would definitely recommend the first six episodes to anyone who has gotten this far into the show - there is no reason to stop before experiencing this. And then they ruin it. And by "it", I mean everything. A lot of dumb stuff happened during Season 2 and S3P1. But it was all still very tolerable. It could have been fixed... or at least you kept telling yourself that. But this was not only the last nail into the story's coffin, as far as I'm concerned, it was also enough dirt to bury the whole thing 6 feet under. ==SPOILERS FROM HERE ON OUT== The entire world we have seen so far, is actually a secluded island. Beyond the ocean, there is an evil mega nation of doom that are persecuting an ancient race of people that once commanded the power of the titans. Their preferred method of execution for the descendants of these titans is to inject them with titan juice and set them loose on the island to terrorize the people living inside the walls. The Evil mega nation of doom, that are now being set up as the primary antagonists, are after the vast amounts of natural resources that can be found on the island. That's the spark behind it all! The nazis want some oil! If this sounds incredibly stupid to you... it's because I'm bastardizing it to hell... But also because IT IS! So, it all took place on an island. We got characters with split personalities. Characters with very selective amnesia. Memory altering magic powers. Inconsistent magic powers that inexplicably work on some people while being useless against others. When your story has elements such as these, you know you are dealing with quite a mess. There are some satisfying revelations here and there but they don't outweigh the tremendous amounts of awful. Also, every new bit of information we have learned about the titans as the show has progressed, has made them less and less cool. What happened to the "grim reminder" the mankind received at the beginning of the show? Living in fear of the titans? By the end of season 3 the characters are talking like the titans aren't even a factor anymore. And they are right! The titans are meaningless. In fact, they kill off all the titans! They JUST do it! Killing off ALL the regular titans, the once insurmountable enemy of mankind, isn't even deserving of a montage. Not even a dialogue scene. It's a passing sentence. One of the most horrific monsters ever created - reduced to this. To wrap it up... The first 6 episodes of the season are a lot of fun. They are what drag my score for the season a little higher than it probably should be, considering the dreadful plot revelations in the final episodes.

IMDB, one of the largest film and tv review sites, has a top episode list made by the collective score the users have given each episode, just like how we do it on MAL. Among the top 10 episodes there are three episodes from AOT s3 part 2. I’d say that is pretty impressive. This season of Attack on Titan is pretty jam packed with action. A lot of revelations come to pass, and a lot of things come to an end. Plot/characters: First this season has some of the highest adrenaline action in all of anime, everything is so well done. There’s not a ... single movement and every scene is amazingly memorable. The second half of the season reveals more about the world, and it feels like a conclusion to the titan story, again it is very well done with scenes of good character conflict, revelations and closing. Animation: Top notch like always. This anime is crowded with fight scenes with amazing animation and the second half has some tranquil scenes which are well designed. Sound/Ost: The music is top notch, a lot of the old melodies repeat from season one, the music really helps boost the action scenes to the next level. Sad piano instrumental tracks during character’s monologue, amazing raging orchestral tracks during charge scenes and emotional strings during sad scenes have been well utilized. Overall, this was peak Attack on Titan and peak anime. A very satisfying season to watch and a nice conclusion to a great chapter of the story.

This is amazing. Truly. It is not just another show with one or two impressive moments. It’s one that has developed many evocative characters with their own purpose and directly pitted those motivations ... their life ambitions ... against the need for their sacrifice in the battle to come. It has built my anticipation of the mysteries to be revealed only to completely surpass my expectations at the reveal. It reinforced themes so tragic and so reminiscent of the real world that it brings tears to my eyes. It swept me up on a roller coaster of emotions with the many twists and turns in a ... fated epic battle ... for which I had no idea what would happen. It has fantastic direction that recognizes all these strong elements in its story and knows exactly how to convey them onscreen. And with music that sends chills down your spine, or completely invigorates you … timed perfectly with dialogue to make you feel the same emotions as those in the story. I … I just can’t even. It’s incredible. It is the definitive GOAT of climaxes in television. There is not a single show out there that has packed so much, so many incredible moments in 10 episodes: that’s 3 hours and 20 minutes of runtime not counting OPs and EDs. Just think about all those 3-hour movies nowadays that almost never justify the runtime. Compare how you feel watching those to this. Can you believe we really got something like this in entertainment? Will we ever get something else like it again? … I write this in retrospective of my immense disappointment with the “final season” of Attack on Titan. Given what was achieved in season 3 part 2, the sequel to it would always disappoint in one way or another. Rewatching Attack on Titan up to this point after finishing the whole series has made me realize that … I was wrong to say Attack on Titan won’t be well remembered because of its ending. At the very least, I’ll remember this show for the rest of my life because of this climax. Beyond just how amazing it is, the themes connected with me on a personal level, specifically because the view of the world presented in Attack on Titan matches my view of the world. I grew up a naïve person and remain that way at heart and act as such without even realizing it. I want to believe that things can work out if people are honest with one another and have that heart-to-heart … and that the world can be a better place if so. But the reality is, people often just won’t do it. And even if they do, one enemy to another, have that heart-to-heart, it’d be a miracle for things to just work out. Now, instead of two people, one country is in conflict with another. Imagine the near-impossible difficulty in having a true heart-to-heart with another country … with all the complexities of diplomacy and politics … all the deep seated hatred from prior wars. And imagine realizing the suffering you would inflict upon others in war should diplomacy fail. It’s a world of hopelessness with a desperate struggle to hold on to optimism. And realize, this isn’t just Attack on Titan. It is the real world.

(I have added all seasons to my personal anime list, and each season will get the same review from me, so I apologize if you have seen this more than once or are about to see this more than once.) When watching a lot of other anime as a new watcher, I had a really hard time getting into a lot of them because for me it was so incredibly easy to predict the plot. For some reason I was always able to tell just how an anime was going to end or in which direction it was headed. That was not the case for ... this show. Every plot twist caught me almost completely off guard. All questions that got answered as the series lead on only lead to more questions that sucked me even deeper into the show. Every aspect of this story was extremely well written from the very beginning to the very end. Going along with the incredible writing, all of the characters are also extremely well written. The speeches given throughout the series and character development that evolves over time will give you chills. Everyone in this anime developed so much and in such a good way for the plot since the beginning. Everything was lined up perfectly for the story to make sense the way it was done. The animation and scenery is also not something to sneeze at. The first few seasons that were animated by WIT studios were very good visually. While there was a lag between season one and two that had a lot of people fall off the Attack on Titan train, the improvement in animation quality over that time is pretty noticeable. The only thing I have negative to say about the WIT studio animation is two things. First, a lot of the aspects that come into play in the later seasons that had originally relied on WIT studios animating certain things that they otherwise didn't made for a confusing time for non-manga readers. While this wasn't completely their fault, it did feel like the ball was dropped about that in the earlier seasons. Second, their use of CGI in the anime felt a bit bulky. While for the time that it had come out it was something that wasn't really seen in popular anime, and it's understandable that with certain things animating it normally would have been a feat, it just felt unnatural to the world. Later on in the series MAPPA studios got their hands on Attack on Titan, and can I just say how incredible their animation was? I remember watching the first episodes they animated and loving the new designs for the characters. The characters looked more true to themselves in regards to the manga. The animation itself had such beautifully dark undertones to it that really highlighted the darkness of the story. And the CGI that was used by them felt much more smooth when it was incorporated into everything. No matter which studio was animating, the music was also something incredible for each season. Every single opening and closing song to this anime has to be some of my favorite songs, along with the soundtracks that play behind action packed scenes. The music always fits the mood and elevates scenes to their absolute full potential. Now that I’ve rambled long enough, I hope this helps you in wondering if you should watch Attack on Titan or not. No matter who asks me if I recommend it, I will always say yes. With a beautifully well thought out story that has an incredible message behind it, to the stunning animation, and playlist worthy music, I think it would be silly for anyone to NOT recommend a show like this!

Shingeki no Kyojin Season 3 Part 2 carries the momentum from Shingeki no Kyojin Season 3 Part 1 and concludes with an exciting plot development to look forward to in season 4.  Each episode is a treat, with action, story, and character development, making this whole season 3 easily the most digestible season of the first 3.  This is peak story telling for anime done in long form 50+ episodes.  Whatever doubts were had over the first and second season were firmly put to rest, leaving only excitement for the viewer going forward. Animation 9/10 -  Incredible at times, with unfortunate horse-riding scenes ... that distract from the overall great imagery, and animation sequences. Sound 9/10 -  Great music, sound effects, with a reuse of season 1 OP, which is fine, but a minor flaw. Story 10/10 -  Great story telling start to finish, with many loose ends from the first 2 seasons bring fleshed out, creating a better overall understanding of the world and its secrets. Characters 10/10 -  Great development of both main characters and side characters, with an intriguing insight into the past. Enjoyment 9/10 -  The most digestible season so far (haven't watched season 4 yet) Overall, season 3 excelled at story telling.  The things that were annoying about previous seasons were not present in this one, which allowed this anime to flourish, thus securing its' spot in one of the most anticipated conclusions in the medium.

I get the hype. The first few episodes felt a bit different, and weren’t particularly strong. In fact, in the first few episodes, there weren’t any Titans at all. It delved into a political story this time, which was interesting, and not in a bad way. Then from Episode 7, Attack on Titan was back to normal. The episodes started getting stronger, and there were some shocking scenes, gruesome scenes and also some beautiful scenes, and still with usual stunning animation. At the start of the second half of this season, it was clear this was going to be good. It got more and more dramatic, and the ... stakes got higher, and then it peaked with the episodes Hero and That Day, which were exceptional. I honestly prefer That Day because the sudden twist and world-building was amazing. Way more mindblowing and well-made than the first two seasons. Warrior from Season 2 is still my favourite episode though.

When I first saw season one I was very hyped for this series and the potential it had. Unfortunately as time went on the story got a bit harder to understand and there was one too many plot twist being used just for the progression of the story. I also didn't enjoy on how some characters were progressing over the others while one character was progressing very well in my opinion the main character kept going down hill and was making no improvements and kept needing to have his friends save his sorry *** (self censored to keep review clean). If our protagonist was actually ... able to do something besides cry this would be a much better show.

To be honest, the first part of the season didn't catch me much, but the second part brings the best of this show, with a lot of surprises and several stuff that got me off my guard, really a good job, got me waiting for the second four. I really liked how they changed the opening too, the other was kinda bad and not suitable for the anime. What I liked the most is how the show is finally solving all those questions you had throught the anime in an addictive way, I didn't feel like it was too fast or if it was too ... quickly, everything happens in the right time and some facts are really shocking, amazing and interesting.

Attack on Titan S3 Part 2 was the best season by far. Eren learns about his family, especially the titan who killed his mother. It is a war and we learn that the identity of the enemies. The Beast Titan attacks the Eldians and there was a lot of heart in this season. This time they didn’t care to kill important characters and two of the characters were put in a critical situation and a difficult choice had to be made. Eren cares nothing about defeating the enemy now. The Royal Family has been established in this season as well. The characters do get developed ... a lot in this season.

This is some of the best anime I have ever watched. All the characters are great in this. The writing is amazing, especially with the reveals toward the end and the inner monologue. The animation is top-notch and the battle is very intense and the choices the characters have to make are difficult. You finally get to see what is in the basement and the reveal doesn't disappoint. In fact, the basement reveal actually gives the viewer more questions. The music and sound is also amazing. Overall, this season made the show an s-tier show. This show has great pacing and the buildup is well ... done. When I think the show is starting to get slow, some new information is revealed and it picks up again.

Honestly, I give this a 10/10 across the board. With the final season of the anime currently airing (At the time of writing this the most recent episode is Epsiode 6) this is as it stands my favorite season of the anime. The character development that the characters went through and the challenges they faced were amazing. The storytelling is also perfectly executed as well as the artwork and sound are perfectly matched to the episode. Overall, very enjoyable 10/10 all the way and I can't wait for the final season to be fully released, and see what happens next! Also, there is something to be ... said about how people in America, season 3 part 1, and season 3 part 2 are listed as just season 3, so I guess you could group them in, and in that respect, there were pretty low expectations at the end of season 2. Fans had high hopes but low expectation so personally, I believe that it not only met expectation but also smashed it out of the park!

Attack on Titan still makes the same mistakes it has been producing since 2013. Bad: —The characters keep explaining things after and as they happen — either in their head or in a flashback. -Not everything needs to be explained! This excess dialogue is slowing the plot down. -I have to admit; I want to know what characters are thinking before they die. However, Attack on Titan rarely does this. —Why did it seem like the Beast Titan knew about baseball when Attack on Titan takes place in 400 something C.E? ....... —Attack on Titan’s art style has always been weird. Still, the Colossal Titan and the Armored Titan’s anatomy and ... CGI is starting to become bothersome. —The Colossal Titan kicked Eren into a wall when it could have kicked him straight to the Beast Titan. What kind of lousy writing is this? I thought the objective was to capture Eren. —I still do not like short piss-stained hair girl. She is only an important character because she has royal blood. Take away her royal blood, and what is she? Regular garbage. She is royal garbage, and I want to see her turn into regular garbage. Good: —I always liked the sounds of Reiner’s armored titan (the mechanical ones and his golem-like ancient voice). —I always wanted to see past events from the enemy’s perspective, and the show delivered in episode three. -Why can they not show flashbacks that people want to see and not waste the viewer’s time? R.I.P Marco —It has come to my realization that Mikasa is a dude. In fact, I like the idea of Mikasa being a dude more than a chick. She can be a girl at heart, though it would please me if everyone addressed her as a guy, and she used her deep voice all the time. —I am not going to spoil, but holy shit, this series is starting to get better! -I can not wait to talk about the plot in my season four review! —They “dealt” with a character I was not too fond of. —Oh my god, Misaka with bedhead hair is doing something to me 😩 —What they did with the Smiling Titan is ingenious. —“Anyone can become a god or a devil. All it takes is for people to believe it.” Jesus Christ, why is this series just now getting so good! —If they end up traveling through the past or to the future, freeze time, destroy time, you name it.... I am going to lose my shit! —I said it in my last review, and I will repeat it! Erwin is an underrated smart character! Now I know what he meant when he asked, “who is the real enemy?” —Floch is a great character. He’s like an attempt for the writers to be self-aware. I love it! Keep showing stuff like this, and I will put Attack on Titan in my top ten list. —This season is giving me “Truman Show” vibes. —Remember these two motifs, freedom and the truth. This series deals with both very well, and I will elaborate more in the final season review. Attack on Titan would be so much better if they combined seasons 1 and 2 into a 20 something season — cutting out a lot of unnecessary context. Also, combine some parts of season 4 with season 3 — cutting out a lot of excessive context in season 3’s parts. If they did that, Attack on Titan would have the best pacing of any Shonen anime I’ve ever seen! I might have to deprive it of a high spot in my top ten list because of poorly written characters and terrible pacing. :(

To me this is where AOT starts getting really good. Seasons 1 2 and 3 all start with a kidnapping plot. It was getting tiresome. Season 3 part 2 is really unique. It has incredible action, tough decisions, an incredible story, and great character arcs. It's the start of peak AOT. Sasageyo! Shinzo wo Sasageyo! Since this needs to be a longer review, I'll just write a small bit more about AOT in general. I binged it all recently. Imo season 2 was basically just a rehash of season 1, with a few differences. I was also disappointed when season 3 started with a kidnapping AGAIN. ... But season 3 part 2 is incredible.

Is there anything to even say? The show that is already a masterpiece and a cultural phenomenon is even more polished is this entry. The return to the Shiganshina District, teased since the beginning of the show, is finally at hand. Tying together so much that has been built up throughout the series, this arc culminates the current story in a such a incredible fashion, that it feels as if it couldn't have been done in any other way. In typical AOT fashion, the ... odds seem insurmountable. The story delivers breath stopping tension and clever, and a believable narrative to address the challenges facing our heroes. What is great about this show, and this arc in particular, is that victory, if and when it comes... is not given. It is EARNED.  It gives meaning to the story progression and makes you that much more invested in the story. Season 3 part 2 marks the final chapter of AOT as we know it, and while excellent in it's own way, season 4 marks a noticeable shift in tone and story. This is "classic" AOT at it's finest. Recommend wholeheartedly.

Absolutely stellar. The second part of Season 3 of Attack on Titan really brings in the heat. A whole host of plot development happens in a very short span. Characters die, plot points are revealed, and setup is given for what happens next (as shown in the manga). Interestingly enough I felt this was a pretty decent setup for the change in Eren's attitude from Season 1 to where he is currently in the manga today. Story: 10/10, they really just drop you in the deep end with the reveals this season. Without any spoilers, suddenly the story becomes less about existential threads as a species, and ... more as a race. Races are brought into the balance of power, as well as more insight onto how these titan powers have played into the history of the world. The show makes you feel for both oppressor and oppressed, as both sides unwillingness to let go of past grievances means they must participate in limitless battle. Art: I always thought the art has been a step down since Season 1 as I liked that bold lined comic style they always had. Animations for titan fights are still stellar though, and I'll not forget the last season with Levi and Kenny fighting in that bar. The animations make for some memorable moments, while the art services the story in a big fashion. Sound: The sound has never been a big part of Attack on Titan, and most are serviceable. Character: Eren really got what I needed out of him for this. You really see why later on he's gonna make some of the decisions he does. He was more in story as I'd argue he's the protagonist. However, great character development also appeared for characters like Armin and Erwin since Levi and Mikasa have already had their time in previous seasons. This really is starting to flesh out the circle of characters we'll be following going into the final acts. Enjoyment and Overall: I mean overall it's a real banger. I enjoyed every single episode whether I was watching a titan battle or pages of exposition laid out for me. There wasn't a single second I wasn't invested, and I think this is really worth your time whether you read the manga or you are watching the show.

Ok first off, this part is good but it shouldn't be the second best rated anime. Spoilers boys The second part of season 3 remembers that the story without the titans is shit and it had not set up anything based on the politics in the walls well enough to carry a story, so they return to what is actually fun. lots of reveals in here as always, good voice acting all around as well as some decent twists that basically everyone knew because manga readers are a thing. However what the show demonstrates over and over again is its action, antagonists and music are just perfect. ... Eren is still just a tool for the plot but we can see him become reliable and Yuki Kaji does excellent work. Levi gets his moment of the series, Berthold isn't just some dude anymore and the pieces are coming together. The Marley backstory while not being as exhilarating as the earlier reveals works fine, it was hinted at and kind of shown way back in season 2 with Ymir and cruel world thing is running through them so it is consistent to the the themes. now the things that are bad. Mikasa has been sidelined since season 1, she has had nothing to do other than kill 3 MP and slice Armored Titan's legs, she is supposed to be an Ackerman, please let her do something. Armin's plan while effective was not like Armin at all, why is the second smartest dude using a brute strategy to kill the strongest titan, there were other ways to get him killed that stayed true to his character. He always used words and logic, planning and predicting before, but now he was just a distraction, also I thought he was all about I killed a human and that added absolutely nothing but I guess we can blame part 1 for that. Also, when they aren't fighting the animation is so stiff, the action looks so good and then next episode you have one piece type of stretching the show and the characters not moving. I feel like the first 2 seasons were much more dynamic. Finally, the edited versions of previous songs are just plain brilliant, the music is what makes this show better than good.

I just don't even know anymore man. Everything has led up to this but I think this is the best season and my favorite season of the show. Every episode left me stunned with either thinking, how on Earth are they going to get out of this one, or just with my jaw on the floor at what just happened, particularly episodes 5 and 6. It's an absolute bloodbath and everything has changed and shifted to how the main cast now relates to the world around them. I knew of spoilers for certain things that were revealed this season in a vague sort of way, ... without knowing any specifics or the plot of the story, but now that it's all come together it just really clicked so well, like, say, a key in a lock. Yep, finally got to that basement and the history of everything was revealed, and adds a certain kind of distance from the main cast that made me empathize more with Eren and how he feels. I was totally locked in for the entire season and now I don't know what to feel about it, so, it's a great time, fun for the whole family.

I remember when the first season of Attack on Titan came out about a 5 years ago, and the hype was real. People tend to lose interests in shows, especially when their seasons slowly come out over the course of years. Attack on Titan may no longer produce the memes and parodies that made the show so popular that even those who did not watch anime at least knew about it, but its quality has not diminished, even at its slightest. It has just gotten better. Attack on Titan Season 3 Part 2 is where everything makes sense. All the questions that were built up in ... the past few seasons finally tie back together to allow viewers to have a cohesive understanding of where titans came from. With lots of background on Eren's dad, dialogue, action, not a single scene was wasted. Trust me on the action part. If you did not love Armin already, you are going to LOVE his fight with the Colossal Titan. If you have not watched the previous seasons already, get started already because this show is definitely worth your time.

Okay, hold up. Did I actually enjoy a part of AoT?? Listen, don't come for me, okay? AoT is good, it's just not my type of good. That being said, this last half of season three was bangin'. Let's start with the obvious praise that we have to give to the art of AoT. Though it's always been a bit bold and extremely detailed, I actually felt like the animation/art was better during this last ten episodes? I'm probably just imagining it, but the art felt cleaner in a way that made everything look nicer while still keeping the AoT aesthetic. Beyond that, I really enjoyed the ... story (for once) the entire way through. I don't know why, but AoT has always been sort of blah for me, so this part of the season grabbing my attention surprised me, and I think I've figured out why: it's the ending to a very long story and the beginning of a brand new one. The way that these episodes brought a lot of things together was very nice. Every episode, you're getting something important to the story that makes everything else you've seen come together. I personally was really happy to have that sort of conclusion to a lot of the open doors we've had thus far. That being said, the season somehow opened a whole bunch of new doors at the same time that gave me back the feeling of awe and anticipation that I had back at the beginning of AoT, when I first started it. I didn't feel like I was getting a lot of unnecessary information this last half of season three. It all very clearly pointed toward what's next. All in all, I usually feel like Attack of Titan is all over the place in my head when I watch it because so much is going on, but this part of the season essentially gathered everyone together in one place and made it a really good bit of anime to watch. I can't really say much because I haven't been this invested in AoT for a long time, but I think, in the future, I'm gonna have a lot more to say. I'm finally excited for Attack on Titan, and I'm pumped to see what comes next.

Attack on Titan Season 3 Part 2, overall a great sequel to the set up season (Attack on Titan Season 3 Part 1) The way this seasons unfolds the plot, the character growth, the details the writers left throughout it, all amazing and very well deserving of its praise it. Though it took 8 years since 2011 to get to this point, it is all worth it. Throughout watching this you will find amazing character development, and a story full of revenge, depression, creepiness, mystery, ideology, a bunch of topics that are really well written and amazingly thought-out since the beginning of season 1. This season hits the hardest, ... when it makes make you try to connect the dots, somewhere along the story it will reveal something to you, but will it quickly cooks up another mystery so that feeling is not lost. The only thing that kinda holds me back is this artstyle, but maybe is just me... Sometimes the artstyle it looks great for creepy horror moments but for the most part I wished it had more care. Other than that I think this season is the best of all Attack on Titan, and you should definitely watch.

Casual reviewers give out 10's like candy and that has never sat well with me. I loved this season of Attack on Titan but I initially gave it a 9. But as time passed by, I couldn't help but bump up the score. AoT S3 Part 2 is the amalgamation of all previous storylines and both executes and improves on what was already incredible - characterization, battles, emotional beats, and world building is all given a boost within 10 23-minute episodes. The final scene in this season is one of my favorite moments in all of anime. Truly an enjoyable ride from start to finish ... and a masterclass in all aspects - if the previous seasons of AoT connected with you I will truly be surprised if you do not feel the same.

(Spoiler ahead) Shingeki no Kyojin 3 part 2 is a fair improvement from previous seasons but When I think about it 6 episodes in, there are still some issues particularly with the script and characters. One of the more iconic scenes in this season is that Levi has to choose to save one from Armin and Erwin, both fatally wounded in the battle. Although I do think the scene itself is handled brilliantly with adequate explanation and enough emotional and physical struggles to render a great impact, it's how the plot progresses to that point worries me. It's crystal clear that when drawing the manga, Isayama ... comes up with this "choose one" scenario first and then proceed to consider how to push the plot to that point, because he does so with incredible amount of plot conveniences and plot armour given to some characters. It's the exact reason why GOT season 8 is terrible and why the story is exciting but also cringe to watch. Heck, Armin somehow survives that burning and over 50 meters free fall, Erwin somehow survives the suicidal charge when he's clearly up in the front, not to mention there's another random soldier who somehow dodged all the rocks just to carry Erwin back. When you realise Isayama clearly comes up with the conflict first then based the plot upon that destination, it becomes incredibly cringe to watch. The amount of plot armour given to Levi and Reiner is also a bit too much. Now I can accept Levi has some crazy skills, but when I see him slaying 20 or so titans single-handedly and cuts the beast titan into pieces like a piece of meat, it's a bit too over the top. Despite all that, the pacing is great and the story is in this constant struggle-solution cycle that easily keep on the edge of the seat (I've read the manga years ago and still feel quite excited during the ride). Part 2 has some of the best animation in the series especially around episode 5 where levi slays the beast titan. Needless to say I do enjoy the first 6 episodes in general, but whenever I think twice about what I just finished, I can't help but to notice some of the aforesaid flaws. Other than that, it's technically 4th season now and the franchise's positive and negative aspects have been discussed numerous times, I don't feel the necessity to reiterate.

In order to write this review I must put aside my bias which is initiated by my 6 year relationship with this show. With that being said, having watched this show since the the moment of it's release I was filled with anticipation and impatience to see how it would eventually unravel. This anime managed to soar past all of expectations and depict the story in ways I'd never imagine. The story alone is outstanding and paced everything in an order that would give just the right amount of information while always leaving the audience eager to see what was to come. At the end ... of every episode of this season I grew more and more thankful for the ending teasers because I would not have been able to wait a week without any hint of what was to come. Each episode was thoroughly thought out and caught me by a pleasant surprise. I was moved by the wonderful development of many of the characters including Grisha. The backstory of the origin of titans was beautifully laid out and the wonderful art style during the ocean scene goes without saying. I feel the ocean scene was my favorite throughout the entire season. For the audience this scene was well anticipated especially surrounding Eren, Armin, and Mikasa. To say the very least it was a complex scene that required many layers of understanding. The audience was granted warm heartedness by the smiles on Armin and Mikasas faces, as for them the ocean symbolized freedom and hope for what was to come. While for Eren, on the other hand, was the complete opposite. He had an understanding of what the outside world was like though his fathers memories that paid him a visit through his dreams. Eren had to carry the burden of knowledge while knowing freedom was farther than they thought. This was a perfect ending to a perfect season of an incredible show.

An anime full of thrills, mystery, action and an ultra active protagonist, nothing much can be expected from an anime. This was my second anime of my life, and nothing beats it. There were some scenes where I had to hop off my chair out of excitement. The fighting scenes, and the thirst of Eren and team to gain their freedom was nothing but mind-blowing. But, this anime was made even better with the help of such high quality sound effects, so a big shout out to Wit Studio. Overall, it is a great anime worth watching. It still holds the no.1 position in my ... anime list.

*REVIEW FOR SHINGEKI NO KYOJIN - SEASON 3 PART 2* Story (10/10): Ok so in my opinion this is one of the best seasons (or better said arcs) every written in any series (TV or anime). Full of plot-twists, epic moments and questions answered, this season's story is hands down the best of the whole Attack on Titan anime. Animation & Art (10/10): Regular Wit animation (9/10) completed by beautiful artistic style (10/10): that's what SnK S3P2 presents you regarding the art of the show. They knew how to make epic moments more epic using very good animation and excellent... >> Sound, Voice Acting & Music (10/10): Easily a 10/10. Everything ... about the music on this season is legendary. The soundtracks, opening, ending are just epic. The voice acting is a 10/10. Character (9/10): The same characters as always are built in the same way. The character development is well-made and manages to keep the characters as "good" as always. Overall, Attack on Titan Season 3 Part 2 is an emotional and legendary season: one of the best of anime, and almost surely the best of all AoT series (so far). Recommendable only to anime enthuasists? : No. Genre: Action, Drama, Adventure.

One of the most engaging stories I have came across in any medium. AOT world feels very much relatable despite being a fantasy one. It was my first anime which naturally brings it close to my heart. For someone who was waiting for all the mysteries previous seasons had built to finally get answered, I have to say it was a perfect payoff. This arc will go down as my most favourite arcs in anime history for all the drama,mysteries,emotions and some of the coolest fight scenes in anime. Judging by the way story have progressed so far I have very high hopes for the ... Final season and I hope it delivers.

This review is a product of the perfect combination of mental illness, alcoholism and a head full of nothing but hatred towards humanity...Just kidding..My head is full of ouzo(if you don't know what that is...Well...Too bad). Now..Shall we get on with Attack on Titan 3? I suppose if you're here then that must mean that you've already watched everything before this , unless you're lost or something. If not just go back and watch the damn thing already. This season was, much like the 2 before it.....Quite different in everything..Season 1 was a great intro to this circle of hell when the wall of Maria fell and ... got introduced to these beau....No they weren't lookers now were they?In fact most titans looked fucking ridiculous..And that was a very big reason for me to not take this series as seriously as i should. I mean if your main attraction isn't threatening looking at all..It kinda spoils the fun, you know? And then season 2 dropped and...I guess the deeper you go the worse it is?......Let's say it was a very different beast than it's 1st counterpart and in all honesty..Much worse in many ways. For one, it felt like a different anime altogether but with the same cast more or less. It's not like it picked right from where the 1st one ended. As for the rest there is already my review on the 2nd one here so go read it you filthy maggots. What, too, was worse...The animation..And this new season is a mixed bag of Part 1 having impressive animation and Part 2 being the bastard love child that got abandoned at the church's footsteps with a note in its' flipper hands..The CG scenes are here as well and as harmful to your eyes as dropping a whole bottle of sulfuric acid directly into them. I don't know what possesed them to make the titans CG as well but god damn, talk about idiotic decisions. A not at all idiotic decision was to shift some focus from the titans to the people themselves and the conflict between humans. To me this was a good thing for 2 reasons..I don't like Eren and the constant reveals of titans...It wears thin after a while when every single person turns out to be one..Back to the conflict, it was that of the lower class and the ruling class(scouts and military police)..Honestly this was way more interesting and action packed than any titan fight i've seen thus far.. The presentation of the first half was far from the offerings of Season 2. The animation, the settings...Man it was great. Don't worry there are fights between titans and massive ones at that and boy did they drag the hell outta them. And the worst BY FUCKING FAR.......The damn Beast titan playing baseball with boulders..Whyyyyyyyyyyyyyy? Just why? I wonder if in future installments they'll have him spit at old ladies and robbing kids from their lunch money.. As for the second half...Well either the budget wasn't big enough or i guess another studio did the work cause they were bored or had other projects going on at the same time? Don't know and don't care..The fact of the matter is that the drop in quality is as vast as the centre of the earth. Another big problem, which i mentioned earlier was the fact that in this season, much like the previous one, there is a feeling of disconnect from the previous ones. In season 2 there were little to no connections between them..And this is made worse when you go from Pt1 to Pt2..It's like the events of Pt1 didn't even matter. There is no sense of an overarching story as such. If you go back from this season to the 1st? It's like those events were from a galaxy far far away..Again why? Did you have anything better to do than connecting the damn dots together? As for the characters...Eren is still an irritating twat when he shows on screen and Mikasa still is..There...In fact i'd say that apart from Erwin and Armin who were the stars of the show, the side characters played a much larger role this time round and i think it was for the best. Now at this point it may look like i shit on this anime way too much but the thing is i still love it and i believe deep in my heart that this is a modern classic..Despite all its' faults i like it for what it is..Sure it has a wooden leg and a glass eye but it has inner beauty..And big perky tits! I'm also hopeful that the last season will somehow fix these problems and amaze us in ways we cannot possibly expect..But here's the thing...I'm not sure this is a likelihood and here's why...In this season they revealed everything there was about the titans and their history..Now the mystery is all but gone and i'm not sure what will be the endgame here..I have this sneaking suspicion that this was the peak Attack on Titan and from now on we are to be made witness to the bottleneck version of things..Still hopeful but...

EXPANDED HERE: https://jeromewei.medium.com/attack-on-titan-sucks-2e639e488c73 Shingeki no Kyojin is a deceptive little piece of work. At its best, it's a mystery show where the characters slowly piece together the secrets of their world, as past events that didn't make any sense at the time start to fall into place. At its worst, it's a show with boring characters, dull militaristic action, and predictable drama. Of course: the real meat of the show is the allegorical world backstory that's finally recovered in this season. Attack on Titan appears on the surface to be allegorical and alluding to historical situations, immediately bringing attention to the centuries-long persecution of the Jewish ... people. Though, that particular comparison is fraught, since the Eldian people seem to have been imbued with some of the most vile of antisemitic tropes---such as having strange transforming abilities and ultimately being a people who once controlled the world and desire to again. My takeaway is then that the sweeping allegorical plot of Attack on Titan is a Rorschach test, up to interpretation, and that interpretation can reveal much about the subject. It can be literally about the Jewish people, it can be about mainland China's subjugation of Hong Kong, it can be about white guilt and Robin DeAngelo's 2018 treatise White Fragility. It can be about Japan's imperial ambitions. There really is no wrong answer, but there isn't a correct one either. Attack on Titan is the ultimate apolitical piece of politically charged media---it takes no stance of its own. The conflict between the Eldians and Marleyians is portrayed as ambiguous. Clearly the Marleyians have become the antagonist and oppressor in the current power dynamic, but the past was clearly less black-and-white (although the extent of that is not clear; how much is Marleyian propaganda is not made certain). Look, right now the Eldians are the good guys and clearly have a right to fuck up the Marleyians, but it's possible that they weren't the good guys back in the day.
