Attack on Titan is really about history itself as an institution and the power of history to create narratives that persist over time. History can be rewritten, as we see with how the CCP justifies its subjugation of the Uighur population, how America justifies the War on Terror. History can be wielded as a weapon, to terrorize an entire group of people and have all citizens on board for it.

This is one of the greatest seasons not just of anime but also the TV shows, they were building up the hype for 2 and the half seasons for this thing. This season will all type of emotions like anger, confusion, sadness, hype.. you will start to question everything that you thought you understood. Few anime seasons manages to do such a thing. Every single minute of this season is masterpiece that is so well crafted. Every single character gets his/her moment and you truly are invested in their past or future. Animation was great, nothing crazy that will blow you away.. but its good enough ... to paint the beautiful story and theme that "Attack On Titan" and specially season 3 part 2 has to offer.

The second part of Attack on Titan, Season 3 might be the magnum opus of the entire series. The emotional tenacity, brilliant characterizations, and stunning revelations make this portion of the series especially memorable. The animation is superb. The visuals are captivating. The way that the story played out was particularly emotional, and the plot twists really elevated the story to new heights. This series has taken a lot of twists and turns to get to this point, and the way that it played out has not disappointed by any means. With a show like this to have such incredible setups that aren't disappointing is ... astounding. The attention to detail is on another level. The way that each and every event leading up to this point and beyond is so important just shows how outstanding the writing is. The thought put into each and every event, and the way that this portion of the season references the prior events leading up to this point is brilliant. The story manages to become even more tragic as time goes on. The sacrifices in this portion of the season are particularly brutal, and the moral dilemmas that are presented don't hold back. This show isn't afraid to present these moral questions in a merciless and unceasing manner. The lore continues to expand and the amount of levels to the story has made this a superb and memorable experience. Needless to say, this particular part of the story is one of, if not my most favorite portion of all. Absolutely incredible the way it built up to this point. I won't put any specific references in so as to not spoil anything, I just highly recommend this.

This anime is seriously so good. Attack on Titan doesn't know how to stop being crazy. Attack on Titan is so full of action, mystery, and suspense, and it's delivered in such an easy to digest manner. The twists are always so surprising, even if you somehow manage to correctly guess what's to come. AoT is just a perfect anime, and season 3 is no different. The second half of season 3 is just as good as the first. It's got all the ingredients that make AoT amazing, but this half gives us a bit more exposition. We've been kept in the dark about a ... lot of things as we follow the Scouts and their traumatic journey, but in the second half of season 3, we start getting some really important answers. Usually, exposition episodes that only serve to explain context are really unappealing to me, but AoT has built up to that point so immensely that it feels like the few exposition episodes that arise are long overdue. They don't feel like filler episodes at all, and you're grateful as a viewer to have more context on this very complex set of circumstances. AoT is just awesome. Shingeki no Kyojin is the perfect anime for people who want a bloody anime that will bring them to tears. It's an iconic anime. Some of us grew up with DBZ, One Piece, etc. The next generation had AoT.

ok here we go aot fan for a long time season 3 part 2 its the aot but better in story telling story 10/10 no argue bout that characters 8/10 we dont se much of the main cast getting much development(at least eren isnt a crybaby anymore) sounds 8/10 as always great job form the studio but my my piece of cake enjoyment 8/10 i legit love this show but isnt as nearly as close to the enjoyment i get from my fav shows overall 8/10 great execution animation is on point sounds great but is a bit far from shows like HxH Code geass and jojo imo still its ... a thrilling ride with high and low points but its far from number 2 spot (this is all based opinions and everybody is free to disagree or to have the same opinion as me)

This is the peak of animation. Without a doubt, people will be talking about this season for years to come. This is Attack on Titan at it's greatest. The culmination of years of foreshadowing, action, and character development comes to a glorious crescendo in this masterpiece of a season. The series could've gone out here and it would've been a bittersweet but great ending. It feels like Isayama gave it his all here and what we have left is good but I don't think will match this season. Spoilers Ahead Let me start with the breathtaking animation. It's what you've come to expect from Attack on ... Titan, fluid and fast paced. The Beast Titan and Levi fight is animated so well, Arifumi Imai was the backbone of the series animation wise. The only problem was the Colossal Titan looked bad and thats pretty much it. The soundtrack is also what you've come to expect, Sawano kills it with his score and it gives each scene that extra punch to hit hard at home. I love this track and to this day, I can't say anything hits harder than the collective soundtrack of Season 3 and S3 Part 2. Now the great stuff. The story is all about taking back Shinganshina and finding Eren's basement. Well, Bertolt and Reiner have something to say about it with their good pals Zeke and Pieck. The arc has a very basic story premise but goes so far, take the city at any cost. This arc sees each of it's characters put to their absolute limits here. Erwin has to make a conscious decision to sacrifice himself and nearly all of his men to buy Levi time to attack the Beast Titan. Eren has to learn that he has to lose people close to him to gain victories. Armin makes the ultimate sacrifice to take down Bertolt. Reiner and Bertolt grapple with the fact they must kill their former comrades. Levi continues to suffer his survivors guilt as everyone around him dies. This season put its characters through hell. Then there's the huge basement reveal. The mysteries of this world unravel as Eren is overcome with rage at the mistreatment of his people. He becomes the genocidal prick who put the Eldians in this situation in the first place. This reveal blew my mind the first time I watched it. It still does. Attack on Titan kept throwing you for a loop until it decided it was going to easy on you and dropped on of the biggest plot twists in history. It's so well written, it puts all of the asspulls that follow it and lesser stories to shame. People will talk about this for years to come. Going in blind was the best decision I've made. I love this season specifically for everything it did. Isayama pulled out all of the stops here and wasn't afraid to brutally murder many of his own characters to get you to feel something. Hero is one of the greatest episodes of any show ever. This episode is ethereal in that it exists. Nothing quite matches its beauty, brutality, and raw humanity. I am not watching a show, this is art. This is why animation is so powerful, limitless creativity. This season left me a changed person, I questioned things. Everything felt so natural, so real. Many live action works will never quite achieve the realism of our characters and their actions and their feelings and their struggles, it is quite ironic. The most unrealistic of mediums portrays it's characters so well, your suspension of disbelief is no longer required. I got so much out of this masterpiece of a season. As a whole, Attack on Titan sits at a 9.2 This season is perfect in so many ways, I can only give it a 10/10. 100/100. 9 dead titan shifters out of 9. In my humble opinion, this is as good as television gets.

Another great instalment by wit studios!. Nothing much to say exept that this will remain one of the most anticipated series for me. Great actions scenes in this part, especially levi vs the ape titan. Subarashii plots, and a freakin great game changing twist awaits in this season, for those who haven't watched. The ending and memoir of girisha has opened up vast possibilities i cant wait to see. The mutual discord between eren ,levi and Mikasa, which was shown post credits in the last episode of season 3 part one, has been beautifully unravelled. The animation is great as always, with innovative action scenes and a ... new gear in this season.  As for sound, i wish the wit studios restarts using german lines in the songs. It seems a bit cooler i guess XD

*Spoilers* This is pretty much The Village, just way better and more interesting. Part 2 of season 3 was so well done. It was able to top the opening of part 1 and there were so many great character moments throughout it. The scene where everyone swings into Shigashina in the first episode was so well done. The music and shot composition was off the charts. I completely lost it when Reiner popped out of the wall and Levi immediately impaled his neck, which is followed instantly by the appearance of the Beast Titan and all the other pure titans. The shot composition and overall quality ... of the sequence as Erwin leads the rest of the scouts on a suicide mission was amazing. I loved that we were able to dive into his psyche in this season as well. It made Levi's justification for saving Armin more solid, beyond the effort that the creator's probably had to keep the audience from rioting if he actually died. I honestly would've been fine with Armin going out in this season. The way he went out was displayed really well and his character would've reached a satisfying conclusion. I would've also been really impressed if the creators decided to take that risk and kill him off. That said, Erwin's death was still a huge blow. The fact that all the other scouts died is an additional sobering fact. Also, I found it really funny that after Armin becomes a titan, he becomes super buff as a human. The only real problem I had with part 2 was the exposition at the end. It wasn't the delivery, I thought it was well paced, rather the content. In the end I came to appreciate it, but the only problem I had was that the reason that the walls were attacked was ultimately to reach the resources that lay under the land, which I felt was very weak. To me it was a very boring reason. Other than that, I loved that the audience was finally able to understand what was going on. It recontextualized a lot of what had happened before and helped us understand why certain things happened the way they did. Finally got our beach episode as well. That ending scene was rough though. It really put into perspective how absolutely bleak the future looks for everyone and especially Eren. He finally reached the place he had been working toward all his life, only to find another wall and another war waiting for him. Can't wait for season 4. My only worry is that since MAPPA is producing this instead of WIT, the quality may not meet the same standard as the past three seasons. I don't have anything against MAPPA, it's just with a studio change you never know what you'll get. We'll just have to wait and see.

Now this is a damn masterpiece let me explain. For the people who love fight scenes in anime or in general will love this and for the people who have lots of questions get answered. The art is damn amazing except for the colossal titan but I honestly don't mind it that much. The sound are just perfect everything is damn perfect. The characters are superb a lot of the characters I did not care about in the past seasons made me still not care about them but some of the characters I love was just going higher and higher I have high expectations for ... this anime going out on my journey.

re-posting my list-comment as review, originally written May 9th 2021: As said in my comments to season 3 part 1; I'm compelled to give both parts of season 3 a 9 individually, because for me they only become a 10 when judged as an entity. Most of my points for this season where already mentioned in my writeups for earlier seasons / part 1 of this season, but as for the episodes of s3 pt2 in particular: The reason I'd deduct a point when looking at ONLY at the second part of the third season is (extremely minor spoiler?) that the day started at ep 1 ... of part 2 lasts until episode 7, which only leaves us with 3 1/2 episodes to go. Now, is this a BAD thing? Not necessarily - a BUNCH of things happen and this runtime is filled to the brim with action, info and PLOT. It's needed! But this is the reason I want to look at the season as a whole, because just looking at the second part feels a bit odd, given that 7 episodes out of the 10 feels basically like one very long episode, which makes sense for the full season as a whole, but makes JUST the second part feel a bit disjoined as a standalone. That being said; I feel like the studio reached it's peak animation-wise in some scenes, and you can really see how they developed when comparing it to their work on the same characters (titans) in earlier seasons. I'm glad I always skipped the opening, bcs it basically spoils the entire ark, and it's (for me) the second least memorable opening song following the one from part 1 of season 3. Not judging openings here though, that's just a sidenote. The reason this still get's a 10 is that this has AMAZING plot-payoff. (minor spoiler if you care for expectation-levels) The third season in general makes the anime SO WORTHWHILE and rewarding to watch. The last few episodes in particular just exceed any expectations you might've had when going into this, unless you'd been spoiled previously or your brain works very different from mine. I don't know WHAT I expected, but I'm very surprised the revelation of the big questions that we asked from the very beginning managed to be both VERY DIFFERENT from what I expected but not disappoint me in the slightest. In hindsight, I wish I had mapped out what I expected the answer to be, because this is so absolutely not what I expected, yet it makes absolute sense. Again, I only give a 10 to season 3 as a combined entity, but I can't bear giving it a 9 for how I was glued to my seat for an entire day binging all 22 episodes when I should've been studying. This season is the reward that has been building up since episode one, and it's amazing! It opens interest in further developments, but at the same time it feels like a very satisfying "ending" - which kinda leaves it up to the viewer if they wanna figure this out altogether once and for all and follow through to the end, or if they're content with the answers we got for our original questions and want to leave it at that.

This is the season that truly made me fall in love with AOT, and it literally has everything you could ask for in an anime. Story 10/10: This is the culmination of the previous 3 seasons.  Everything feels perfect, with finally one of the greatest reveals of all time in the end of Season 3 part 2.  This truly is the turning point of Attack On Titan, and you would never guess how Season 1 could lead to this. Art 9.3/10: Again just the CGI for the colossal titan, everything is amazing. Sound 9/10: Great opening, great soundtracks. Characters 9.3/10:  Although not as ... good as last season, it has many satisfying ends to many character arcs, and more clarification on how Reiner, Annie, and Bertholt acted the way they did.  Eren's dad also went through an amazing arc in the flashback in the basement.  Armin really found himself this season and I felt like he was the highlight of the season.  And lets not forget Eren said right before the season ended... Enjoyment 10/10:  Amazing Story, a constant thrill ride, and great emotional impacts, what could you ask for. Overall 10/10

"Attack on Titan" is often hailed as one of the best anime series of all time, and for good reason. From its unique storyline and well-developed characters to its stunning animation and gripping action sequences, "Attack on Titan" is a series that stands out as a masterpiece of the medium. One of the things that makes "Attack on Titan" so unique is its premise. The world of the series is one where humanity lives in constant fear of Titans, giant humanoid creatures that devour humans seemingly without reason. The show explores the psychological and emotional impact that this fear has on the characters, creating a sense ... of tension and suspense that keeps viewers engaged from start to finish. At the center of the story is the main character, Eren Yeager. Eren is a complex and nuanced character whose motivations are driven by a desire to protect his friends and family, as well as a burning desire for revenge against the Titans who have caused so much suffering. His journey throughout the series is one of growth and self-discovery, as he learns to grapple with his own limitations and face the harsh realities of the world around him. But Eren is far from the only compelling character in the series. The supporting cast is equally well-developed and interesting, each with their own unique motivations and personalities. Characters like Mikasa Ackerman, Armin Arlert, and Levi Ackerman all add depth and complexity to the world of "Attack on Titan," making it feel like a living, breathing world with real people living in it. Of course, the animation and art style of "Attack on Titan" are also major reasons why the series is so highly regarded. The action sequences are beautifully animated and choreographed, with each fight feeling like a visceral and intense experience. The art style is gritty and realistic, adding to the overall sense of realism and immersion that the series is known for. But perhaps the most impressive thing about "Attack on Titan" is the way it tackles complex themes and ideas. The series explores ideas of freedom, sacrifice, and the human condition, using its fantastical world and characters to explore ideas that are deeply rooted in our own lives. It's this depth and complexity that sets "Attack on Titan" apart from other anime series and makes it a standout work of art. In conclusion, "Attack on Titan" is a series that deserves all the praise and accolades it has received. From its unique premise and well-developed characters to its stunning animation and gripping action sequences, the series is a masterpiece of the medium. It's a work of art that explores complex themes and ideas in a way that is both accessible and thought-provoking, making it a must-watch for anyone interested in anime or storytelling in general. Whether you're a long-time fan of the series or just discovering it for the first time, "Attack on Titan" is an experience that will stay with you long after the final episode has aired.

Well Attack on Titan season 3 overall was really mind blowing in some ways and I still feel like I didnt fully understood some scenes. So after I finish watching this anime, there is big chance for me to rewatch it in a near future once again cause its story and characters are to complex for one time watch. Story was during whole season engaging and interesting and it keeped my eyes glued to screen while characters had some badass but also some sad moments. Animation was very pretty and some visual aspects of fights were really amazing to look at . So , I feel ike if you ... liked previous seasons ,you will love this one even more and it will build you up for the final one.

This season was absolutely incredible! I don't even have words to describe how good this show is, especially in this season. All the development and all the buildup come together, and it is absolutely insane. The animation is great, the music is great but most of all the plot and would building is honestly some of the best stuff i have ever seen in a anime. Isayama is a absolute genius! Going into the show I just assumed it would be about a boy fighting monsters, BOY WAS I WRONG. It is show much deeper than that, watching season 1 to season 3, the audience ... has no idea for the wild ride they are in for. The basement scene was all worth the wait. The show will never be the same for me now. Also what I think is insane is the amount of foreshadowing. Like the second ending of season 2 basically spoils the whole entire reveal but without the context behind the creepy images one would have no idea what it all means, but this just goes to show how talented Isayama is and how much planning he truly put into the story. I have seen other animes do insane stuff but Shingeki no Kyogin does it the best imo. This hands down is the best season of this show. Everything good about the show is elevated by like 100 in this season.

My blown mind has just been blown even further.....I don’t actually think I’ll get it back! I’m going to start at the end. This conclusion is satisfying, even considering how much we have lost by this point. For those of you, the lucky ones, who will be watching this for the first time after season 4 has concluded, I can guarantee you will be watching season 4 immediately. It leaves you screaming for the next season. The continuation of the story is exceptionally well told. It is as wonderfully paced as Attack on Titan has ever been. It takes you on a journey through devastating loss ... to euphoric joy, from darkest space to the brightest place. There are no more words i could possibly write to truly express how amazing this story is other than phenomenal. Although part 1 will hold, and I am pretty damn certain of this, the most perfectly written and animated action sequence of all time, this season had one of the most emotionally engaging. For those of you that have watch Gon vs Pitou, it’s almost the same level as that and it comes towards the climax of the season. I really can’t say anymore without going spoiler crazy. In my personal opinion, if I was to look at this season alone, Attack on Titan would be the greatest anime ever written, it’s that good. Flawless story telling, exceptional animation and emotionally engaging. It really is a perfect season. The realisation of everything that you’ve seen comes together as one perfect picture at the very last scene of this season and shows how good conclusions can be. A truly exceptional piece of work and again, in my opinion, one of the best seasons, of not the best season of anime I have ever seen. Absolutely perfect in every way.

Here you are after watching 1st part of Season 3. Now, I will tell you that once you finish part 2, you will see how incredible Attack on Titan is, and how story is the best anime story ever. Emotions and feelings you'll get during watching it will be at the biggest level, you will rather be sad or happy matters who will die and who will be alive, willl it be your favourite character? Opening hypes you the most, but contains also a lot of spoilers. What else can I say... just go watch it before you find spoilers, becuause this Season presents the biggest spoiler in Shingeki ... no Kyojin.

Well not much to say really apart than JUST WATCH IT !! XD First season was magnificent with its original plot, second one a bit mehhh but with this season everything is stepped up a notch. Artwork: Was always a great anime to look at but with this season everything is dialed to 11 amazing at all times and the fighting scenes are simply breathtaking. Plot: Original and in this season takes a very large twist and a lot of questions are answered at last XD. A cliffhanger at the end of every episode leaves you guessing whats gonna happen next. Characters: Simply great apart from a couple ... of them you really form a bond with a lot of them. One of the best anime out their has whole package and will always leave you on edge at whats gonna happen next; wont regret giving your time and for sure will be one of your favorites :)

This has to be my favorite season of AOT besides the second season. The transition from season 3 to season 3 part two was a little rough in my opinion. But the art and voice acting were beautiful. This season made me cry but i'm not mad about it. Some characters that were introduced this season were a bit forgettable and felt unnecessary but they weren't too bad. Overall I'd recommend watching this season. I feel like you could stop here and just read a summary of season 4. Imo, you could just stop at this season if you don't have time to watch the ... next one.

I'm not willing to make a review for each season of Shingeki no Kyojin so this review will count as one big review for the whole show. Theres a summary at the bottom if you're like me and dont wanna read all this shit (Spoilers) General Review: I first started watching AOT in 2018 as my first anime ever, and I dropped it in the 1st season because I had a problem with commitments, but I still loved it. I still have memories of how cool it seemed and how new everything was, and that influences my score for sure, but it still deserves its perfect ... score, even if AOT isn't perfect. Like any show it has its rough points - lame soundtrack that isnt even in Japanese, boring dialogue and slow pacing in S1, and some wonky CGI, but all of that is made up for by the incredible story and concept. The worldbuilding is extremely well done. Story: The story is amazing. I didn't get spoiled for the entire show so I pretty much got the ideal AOT experience, and I didn't see any of the twists coming because I'm a fucking dumbass. I love everything about the story. Art: Its pretty good. I don't like the thick black lines that outline pretty much everything and I'm not a big fan of how hazy everything looks in S4, but I can still appreciate it. The lines are pretty much pointless but you can interpret the haziness of S4 as a feeling of uncertainty about the world that has just been revealed to the Eldians I guess. Sound: The OST rocks and Sasageyo is amazing. Except for one or 2 cringey songs in s1 and 2 the OST slaps. Character: It's ok. The reason its not a 9 or 10 is because Eren confuses the hell out of me. I sitll dont get his reasons for doing everything at all, and I've read the manga. But all the other characters are pretty cool. Enjoyement: So much fun to see Levi chop up titans and shit Overall: 10/10 show IMO, if I'm being objective its probably more like a 9 or 8 but because I had the optimal experience and didn't get spoiled at all and watched the first season when I was young and dumber, it gets a 10.

Attack on Titan Season 3 part 2 is arguably the best Attack on Titan season that has ever been produced till date ,the consistency in this season is incredible ,it is really hard to come back strong and please almost 95% of the fans when season 2 or season 3 could only please a few percentage of them. Here is a short review on why i feel AOT S3P2 is an absolute modern classic(without spoilers) Story(10/10):No matter how many times i rewatch this arc ,the part that stands out to me is the immense consistency and hyped this arc generates ,not only in the action/suspence department ... but the shocking reveals and calm before the storm ending, there is no random bullshit, random out of character moments, random explosions(like most other shounen animes), it all feels like it is planned and well directed, Isayama sensei worked immensely well on this arc ,from a tense buildup to epic important moments to a slap on the face plot reveals( that pays off in a stunning way that even after 3 years i still remember it) to a well balanced ending to the arc. The vibe and atmosphere this arc create is just fantastic and pleasing to the eye and mind. The execution is a bit off at times, but it does not take away from the high moment. Art/Animation(9/10):The art and feels is really really good but the animation can be off at times and dragged out .Art(10/10), Animation(7/10). For those complaining about the colossal titan CGI , i absolutely disagree with their opinion, Infact, it actually works well for the atmosphere it creates, if you see the hand-drawn colossal titans in season 4 part 2 they may look nicely animated but the overall atmosphere feels dull as compared to one colossal CGI titan in season 3 part 2 ,the actual problem is the inconsistent animation of the titans and sometimes the background does not match the foreground. while the art in this arc is absolutely other worldly take for example the last 3 episodes, that ancient type of feel it gives to the story with the yellow-brownish filter and well detailed surrounding and art work really blends well with the atmosphere Sound(9/10):Easily the worst part of season 3 part 2, aside from the endiing and opening sequence the ost's aren't that well thought out ,at some places it does work really well while in other places it creates a bit of annoyance while trying to concentrate on the show, i do like that in few of the episodes they decided to not incorporate any music and it worked really well for the situation, that approach was a genius move Character(10/10):The only AOT arc that has every character on the edge of their character limit, everyone had some or the other role to play with a wakeup call of anyone dying , the stakes were really high even for the background characters, it truly felt like a battle of wits, and showcased how everyone were so messed up in their heads that as a viewer you feel for the bad guys and the good guys , not knowing what will be unfolded before our very eyes, there are some characters that  you will want them to survive while there are some you wish they better die a miserable death. The scouts were at their absolute best performance . Then there are characters that were never introduced before who impacted the plot in very surprising ways that connect to the events of previously build-up seasons while at the same time setting-up for a fantastic Final season ride. Some characters developed more than expected . while some faced massive emotional damage overall the characters in this arc got equal development and screen-time. Enjoyment(10/10):Tense, heartbreaking, memorable, betrayals, emotional, anger, sorrow, hopefulness, wholesomeness, craziness, badass and calmness. Overall: In my opinion the Best AOT season and the third Best arc of the story overall

The latter half of Shingeki no Kyojin Season three was quite a ride, with the first part being entirely focused on epic, bloody battles, and the second part being filled with one of the biggest reveals in anime: what's in the basement? The first half kept me on the edge of my seat with its high-stakes action scenes, while the second kept me interested with the reveal, and all of its implications and extensions. The fights of this part of the series were quite good, with the highest stakes seen in the series, as well as the most dire circumstances. The action itself was well animated ... and interesting to look at, although I think the fights had some slightly infuriating conclusions, although I don't see it really as a negative. Good fights are an important part of any season of Shingeki no Kyojin, and this one certainly delivers. The story was pretty amazing for this cour of the series, probably the best so far. The dramatic moments during the climactic fights of the first half are potent and strong, with plenty of drama and emotion to spare. The second half features the massive reveal, which I do think feels a little bit on the "completely out of left field" side of reveals due to the scale of the reveal and how involved it is, but I think that it was appropriately set up, with many things that occurred throughout previous parts of the series all lining up nicely. Since it's setup was done quite well I feel that it's scale only enhanced it, rather than making it seem outrageous and stupid as it likely would have happened if it was done with less proper set-up. The art is as good as it always is for Shingeki no Kyojin, with the exception of some dodgy CGI. Other than that it was as good visually as always. The music was also great, with a really great OP that I'll likely remember clearly for a good while. Overall I think this is likely one of, if not the strongest pieces of Shingeki no Kyojin. It has the action of titanic proportions we all love, as well as completing the task of answering the biggest mysteries of the series. It contained everything I could want from Shingeki no Kyojin and more, and makes me excited to start the final stretch of the series.

Attack on Titan is by no means a perfect show. I think in many ways it is very overhyped but it is hard to deny that this season in particular is just a superb peice of entertainment, of any kind. The animation is beyond epic; the music - which I'd always thought was excellent - is as good as ever but seems elevated by the higher stakes of the story; the characters have always been somewhat lacking in Attack on Titan but due to some solid development in season 2 and the first half of season 3 they are better here than they ever have ... been before. Season 3 of Attack on Titan, both halves, will forever be one of the highlights of watching anime for me and I highly recommend you watch it.

I rate this a freedom/10 good character dynamic surely the show does not flop its ending with something complicated (general audience opinion; I tend to do research after to get some more fulfillment) but all jokes aside the next seasons are only going up. What will happen? Will Eren find "freedom"? Will he take his vengeance for the death of his mom, friends, and freedom from being inside the walls? Will eren ever find the answers to his fathers whereabouts and the full truth about the basement? Will the viewers ever get to know what Eren saw when he touched Historias hand? Answers only to ... be found in the next season of Attack On Titan! 9/10 MAL is making me write a essay to write a funny review leave me alone god damn, check my profile out and friend me if we got the same taste tt: ohcloudy

This season we really got to see Eren Jaeger develop as a character, and he experienced arguably the most traumatic events in this season alone, which is saying a lot based on previous seasons. However, rather than talking about his character, it is the writing behind his character, the directing, the animation, and the sounds that all brought it together into such a masterpiece. The writing, by Isayama of course, is masterful just like every other manga chapter that he has made. This goes for every character within the series, but specifically Eren, Reiner, and Levi stand out as some of the most complex and ... well written characters. Their backstories, hardships, and character development really bring them together. For Eren, this season you really watch his character break, watch him become someone completely different than the basic Shonen character that he was in Season 1 and 2. As the the directing and animation, that was amazing. The fight scenes are so well made and bring all kinds of emotion make it very immersive. It brings the characters to life and finalizes the huge emotional attachment that starts to develop in Season 1 and 2. As for the sounds, the voice acting is PHENOMENAL. I mean, all of their voice actors take the cake for some of the most real and raw voice acting that I have seen (I watched in sub). Specifically Eren's titan roars and the sounds of the ODM gear, plus the music really bring it all together. This is probably my favorite season of Attack on Titan as of yet, even after watching season 4 (which was also amazing). Personally, I don't think that any other series will top Attack On Titan for me, but this season specifically was just, wow.

This is exactly what was needed after the slower paced part 1 of season 3. It focuses around one battle and you see some very emotional moments. A lot of characters really have a great moment for themselves like Erwin, Levi and Armin. One scene in particular involving all three of them was one of the most intense scenes I have ever scene. The titan fights were reallly good and in my opinion Levi really stole the show with his plan with Erwin. Once the battle is over however it does slow down a bit but it does not really matter cause we were rewarded ... with such a great fight.

What an amazing season! This might be the best Attack on Titan season of all time. The whole fight and action choreographies are on point. The animation looks top-tier. We can finally see the true successful attempt and victory of the Scout Regiment against the Titans. Levi has become the most feared and deadliest member of the regiment, Armin is now finally a truly important member and a lead, and we can finally get to see Eren Yeager's house, where all the secrets and history of Titans are resting. Honestly, there are no downside in this one. Overall, the most entertaining season of AOT.

This anime is just simply amazing. There is no other anime that hooked me like Attack on Titan. The plot, the music, the fights, all just amazing and some of the best entertainment television has to offer. Here is my points on why AOT season 3 part 2 is one of the best shows ever made. Story. 10. While a little slow at first, this story really picks up the pace after season 2. This show always has you on the edge of your seat, and this season was no exception. It has some of the best action and dialogue i have ever seen. The moment ... the return to Shiganshina, the pace and action picks up and never slows down till the end. But the best part of the whole show in my opinion, is the basement reveal. This was probably the biggest plot twist in anime history, and was one of the best moments i have ever witnessed on TV Art. 10. Do I really to explain why Attack on Titan is a 10 for art? Sound: 10. Every opening in this show is absolutely exceptional and deserves all the praise it receives. And the battle music is also something to behold. I have never heard more upbeat and awesome music in any other show. Props to linked horizon for creating these masterpieces. Characters: 7. Overall, the characters are pretty boring, generic shounen tropes.( with the exeption of commander Erwin and Captain Levi) most are pretty boring Overall: 10. Excluding the characters, this show is perfect. Absolutely loved my time watching this and i cant wait for the final season. Basement reveal was some of the most entertaining and intriguing episodes of TV I have ever seen.

Shingeki no Kyojin Season 3 Part 2 maintains and exceeds the high standards set by its predecessors, delivering gripping action spectacles, dramatic moments, and significant character development. The series continues to be driven by its compelling mystery, which unfolds and reaches resolution by the season's conclusion. It's not an exaggeration to say that the season finale fundamentally alters the series' trajectory, setting the stage for significant changes in its future direction. The pacing in Season 3 Part 2 is impeccably tight, ensuring that every moment serves a purpose without overstaying its welcome. This results in a narrative that is consistently engaging and impactful. While the series still ... grapples with poor CGI, it is notably improved compared to previous seasons, allowing the visual spectacle to shine through more effectively. Overall, Shingeki no Kyojin Season 3 Part 2 is a triumph that builds upon its predecessors' strengths. It delivers thrilling action, emotional depth through character development, and resolves key mysteries while setting up intriguing new directions for the series. Despite lingering CGI issues, the season stands as a testament to the series' ability to captivate and innovate within the anime landscape.

Attack on titan was the anime of the year in 2013. The hype behind the show was immense and it seemed unlike anything I had ever seen at that point. Some of the elements that made the show stand out where the gruesome scenes, the frequent killing of characters from episode to episode, the booming soundtrack, incredible art/character design and the pure unadulterated moments of hype. Every episode just hooked me in, making me continually go from episode to episode. If I couldn’t watch another episode immediately, I spent the next day just looking forward to the next moment I could watch another episode. Once season ... one ended, the hype for more of the show was still strong. However, another season wouldn’t emerge until 4 years later. At this moment, my interest in the show had significantly waned as I got interested in other shows. I gave season 2 a shot and it wasn’t what I was expecting. For one, the main characters of Eren, Mikasa, Armin and show favorite Levi weren’t really focused on. Instead, new side characters that I had simply forgotten about such as Reiner, Christa, Bertholdt, and Ymir were being focused on from episode to episode. Also, the questions most of the fanbase wanted answers to (i.e. What was in the basement?) weren’t answered. Season 2 just felt different from the first season. Season one had the feeling of a horror thriller with tons of blood, gore, death, and fighting to go around. Season 2 felt extremely understated. It had more of a mystery feel with the 12 episodes being spent developing the lore and characters more. I will say I was a little disappointed by season 2. It wasn’t bad, but it was no season one by any stretch. Even during season one, I was a little disappointed that attack on titan wasn’t as unique as it seemed. Despite the death of many main characters, the viewer could be relatively certain that the main characters were safe. Also, the protagonist, eren Jaeger, acted as a standard shounen protagonist driven by the goal of eliminating evil. Also, the fact that he became a half human/titan just made it feel like another shounen. Characters didn’t feel very developed and the lore seemed to indicate it was going in a predictable direction. I decided to give season 3 a shot once I saw how the scores for the season were actually fairly high. I was glad I did when I first started getting into the new season. For one, the 3rd season acts as a sort of combination between the first two seasons. It has the hype, death, and gore of the first season with the mystery of the 2nd. The first half of season 3 practically turn most of the elements of the show on its head as new, unexpected enemies are revealed and characters work to discover what’s behind a giant conspiracy. This new development pushes the show in a new direction, as other characters start getting new development with explored backstories and harsh moral dilemmas. One of these characters happens to be Levi, someone who we see do amazing things in the show a lot without knowing how he came to be the way that he was. One strength of attack on titan is subverting the viewers expectations, one minute everything seems fine and then all hell breaks loose. This is not only present in the new season, but it is in a new form. For one, there are many moments where characters have to make choices that could honestly go either way. These choices have massive implications to the story and the moments before and after these choices are made hold the viewer’s attention all the way through the episode and beyond. In addition, the fleshing out of the anime’s lore makes the show infinitely more interesting than before and encourages them to keep watching to find out more. While I might have written off attack on titan as predictable and lacking any factors special to it before, I have changed my opinion on it now. Sometimes, the show will showcase characters that act like villains and seem completely underdeveloped. This often times isn’t the case since attack on titan is one of those anime that seems to hold its cards close to its chest. This means it continually gives you small pieces of information that keep you invested while withholding the rest. The writers of the show do this masterfully. So, while some characters seem underdeveloped, it is really the case that their development is just withheld for later on. I had initially lost interest in where Attack on Titan was going, but this new season drew me back in. All the elements people love about attack on titan are already here with new elements added in. Season 3 acts as a sort of cathartic release where the viewer’s patience is finally rewarded with at least some answers to our many questions. Credit must be given to the author of the manga who seems to continually evolves his story and shifts focus from character to character. Honestly, the layers of this show are numerous. It is a show that gets better with age. I keep watching to see how the world evolves and how the characters still manage to survive. When attack on titan got really big, it almost seemed like it was in a position to take the spot of one of the shounen big three. Now, it seems like it has earned that spot both by being massively entertaining and going against the current grain of anime. If you have made it to the current season, you already know you like the show. At this point in time, I am just on the journey to see where the story and characters go next. Attack on titan certainly did get better, I just happened to sleep on it. Don’t make my mistake!

Okay, this season is not over yet, but I know the next episodes will disappoint me (I read the manga) so I'd rather write my review now xD. I'm not a fan of SnK. Never have been, never will be. However, it does do a lot of things right. This season 3 part 2... is no exception. It was full of awesome moments, the visuals and sounds are great, and the story covered in this part is probably the most important point since season 1 and they didn't screw it up. However, it also does contain everything bad about SnK. STORY In this part, the crew has to fight ... Reiner and Bertholdt (along with the Beast Titan and their army of normal Titans) in order to retrieve and repair the broken wall. If they succeed, they'll have the opportunity to finally get into Eren's basement and discover the ultimate truth. I love that pitch. Although it pretty much sums up this dozen of episodes, so in terms of content, it doesn't tell much. However, the lack of story points is really not important given how well they handled the few lines I wrote above. - The battle is full of strategy. - The episodes aren't stretched, there are no useless dialogues (like in the first part of season 3, for example). - Each episode has its brillant moments that will make you say "wow, now THAT was clever!" This is all good and all, but you can't expect me not to put in evidence the one main flaw, which has been present since season 1: the terrible narrating. Let me explain: - Many things are explained several times. It happens a lot in the battle. There's that one time when Armin tells a plan, then we switch to Reiner and we hear him discover the plan. As a result, the viewer hears the same thing twice in a row! Dude! I'm not stupid! You don't need to tell me something that simple twice! - The author clearly doesn't know how to handle flashbacks. At one point in the middle of the battle, there's a flashback about Marco. Who's been dead since season 1. No point in showing him again, especially when that flashback actually doesn't show anything relevant to the battle or the characters. Now I'm nitpicking here. Despite these flaws, the season was very enjoyable. Sadly, this battle is where the story stops for me. I hate what it becomes next. So I'll have to drop the show, but I'm glad I end up with such a memorable season. ART This is where things start to get messy. Yes, SnK has great visuals overall. - Great environments. - Some great animated scenes. - Detailed and dynamic fights. But it also has the same flaws as the previous seasons, namely: the chara-design. - It feels too flat most of the time. - The edges of the characters are WAY TOO THICK and COMPLETELY IRREGULAR. Edges are important because this is what makes the characters blend in the environment. Instead, it often feels like the characters are paste [i]on[/i] the environment. It's simply wrong. - The shadows are often hashes, which looks awful and non-realistic. Realism wouldn't be important in many other show, but this one tends to have a realistic feel, so... it's definitely wrong to get hashes. Also, the animators definitely want to get rid of those, as they are pretty rare compared to the previous seasons. It's like they put hashes as an "early stage shadow" and they just didn't have time to remove them before the release. Also, the CGI used for the Colossal Titan is... pretty bad. I wasn't bothered by that, but be warned if you don't like the use of CGI in anime xD. SOUND The OST is still epic as hell. The seiyuus are great, especially Yuki Kaji, as usual. But I didn't like the opening at all. Musically speaking, it was bad. There's a part that's not even sung... And the only good parts are the ones they copy-pasted out of the very first opening. CHARACTERS I've never been fond of the characters in SnK. Most of them are flat and barely have any story. When they do have a story, they become completely transparent once said story is introduced. I'll take Sasha and Connie as examples. They had one moment each in the previous season, now they're just... like ghosts. They're here just because they're here. The same for Christa, who didn't even appear in this whole part. Of course not, her story is over! Really, this is a big issue as this concerns each and everyone of them. ENJOYMENT This season 3 part 2 has everything wrong with this anime (misuse of flashbacks, ugly chara-design, overall flat characters), but that didn't prevent me from enjoying the hell out of it! The battle was epic, probably the best I saw in this series. It was clever, it had a lot of memorable moments, and that's all I expected. I loved it! And I know I'll hate season 4, so I won't bother watching it. But I'm happy with what I saw. In my opinion, SnK is definitely not the best anime ever. But it was definitely great.

F's REVIEW: Everything that has happened so far was to get here, and everything that will happen from here is just consequence of that. Right on the first episodes of Shingeki no Kyojin's first season, we are given only one assurance out of this cosmos full os mysteries and doubts: there's a cellar, and in it there's an answer. And I confess I wasn't so sure about it. I knew that this season would kick off with physical combats, which brings me bad memories from season 1 and its countless melodramatic flashbacks and graphic violence. I knew it would diverge from the last season's tone, which took ... its time on a construction of a carefully faceted mythology so wide for this fantastic universe. Yeah, I still think the rich of the series is in all those details that built this diegesis. The battles, as well as any threat that puts the characters in a life-or-death situation, have a history of being traps for its own narrative that, abusing the climax of these moments, take a chance to beg for some of the public's tears. And as the previous season inferred, it's not necessary this much effort when the situation makes use of the thoughts and relationships of and between the characters. With maturity and temperance in the approach, it just takes storytelling what must be storytold. Less is more. That's why the last episodes of this season simply change everything that has happened so far. With minor spoilers ahead... when we get to the episode of the "choice", when we're taken to a cul-de-sac where one of the characters must die, the maturity the anime reaches in this moment is enough to redefine the show's whole tone. So far, all those battles full of violence and stunning maneuvers (that benefitted a lot from the incredible animation design, to say the least) provided us moments of attention and tension and, when effective, emotion. The care the anime has taken in the relations and little gestures between the characters and even on the minimal objects scattered through the frame, from the 5th episode onwards, makes any of those physical conflicts as a low priority. It's this what the whole show's about. Not about vengeance, villains and heroes or any Manichean concept so ubiquitous in shônen animes. It's not about combats. It's about those details that drive us directly into that world's atmosphere - and what a world and what an atmosphere. Even Eren Jaegar, a character I had criticized an awful lot in previous reviews, came out better than started off in this season (at least in the sense of growth and multidimensional development). Even though I still get bothered with the absolute unnecessary choice of those flashbacks we already know of and are used to, at least here we get a better use of these mnemonic elements when we get access to an unknown genesis -- something that's been happening to help the character's building since season 2. In the perfect world this quality should've been kept in the whole 10 episodes, but I can't help thinking that the first ones, when the action's still the "conducting wire" of the screenplay, there's still a hard time in keeping the conflict as organic and mature as the "moments-in-between", generally resorting to some genre clichés, including those Manichean concepts I believe are abolished in the season's second half: the ReinerxBertholtxSurveyCorps arc deserved better. Anyway, the satisfaction in seeing an anime make way for such an ambiguous ending, and I say that as a compliment, is more than enough for me to expect the best conclusions for its next events. With an universe so well architected, both in time as in space (and signs of what might seem to trascend them both), I can't but root for the anime to honor its characters the same way they honored in this last stage, setting them up so well in addition to what surrounds them. Therefore, it won't be necessary no tears thirsty flashback: the consequences here are more shocking than the action, and reflect about them alongside our protagonists it's an experience that few audiovisual products got the chance to offer to its public like Shingeki no Kyojin potentially can make it in its final season. After all, who's the enemy? ~~~~~~~~ P's REVIEW: Succintly sayin', the part 2 of Shingeki no Kyojin's 3rd season is wonderful. I mean... it's the best season so far, keeping the quality just as expected. There are TONS of mysteries that were solved but, most importantly, TONS of new mysteries for us to think about incessantly 'til season 4. Even the protagonist turns out more interesting - takin' into account that I always thought he was annoying as hell throughout the previous seasons. Being the aesthetics impeccable as always, full of exciting action scenes well detailed, stories well developed for the characters and dramaturgical consistency, this gets to be one of my favorite anime seasons. I can say, for sure, this is a MASTERPIECE. thank you, bye ~~~~~~~~ F's RATING: 75/100 P's RATING: 95/100 MEAN SCORE: 85/100

Probably the best season yet. Waiting for them to animate season 4 correctly which is a banger. This season showed the plot of the story and took some time but everything was well explained and all the details of the show are there. I love how the episode That Day specifically. Turning point of the show for me. There are episodes too that made you feel emotional and you just got to sympathize with the characters. They were able to present the story well going in with what will happen in the future events. Isayama probably loved shows like GOT and Breaking Bad that's why ... he kept on using foreshadowing and parallelism on this Anime. All in all a great Anime and hoping to get a higher rating in the coming years once the series is over.

If you have watched the seasons before and thought it couldn't get any better, you were gravely  mistaken. My review: To begin, the story picks up where it left off, and it finally shows us EVERYTHING. Why they live behind the walls, the history of the titans, Erens purpose, who the real enemy is, and much more... The art is amazing as always. The fight scenes are fluid and beautiful so are the effects, and everything else. I don't know how they do it but in my opinion this opening is even better than the 3rd one. Its like they combined all the previous ones and what ... came out was simply amazing. The soundtrack is great too. The characters do get some development, there is drama and tragedy(like always). Still loved it though. If you enjoyed the previous seasons this one will leave you speechless. In my opinion this part is a masterpiece, everything has been done masterfully. It truly is magnificent.

This is the season where this anime finally got really good. No, actually great. Many of the things in the earlier seasons lacked explanations and some characters lacked proper motivations for their actions. What happens in many series is that questionable things, like mentioned earlier, are often neglected, forgotten or explained in outright unreasonable ways. Exactly this made me sceptical towards this series. But alas, basically all of my concerns have been answered, and well at that. I can no longer question the greatness of this series. This raises an interesting point. Should this season retrospectively increase the score of the previous seasons? The other seasons ... basically had to be the way they are, I think, for this season to actually be as great as it was. So I believe it’s right to still view the previous seasons as worse, although this season makes the series great as a whole. If I had more faith that the series would actually manage to tie everything together in the end I might not have rated the previous seasons as bad as I did. I do believe that the previous season could actually be better by hinting more at what was to come. It almost came out of nowhere, almost. I realise now that what I’m about to say is somewhat of a spoiler, but you have been warned. This reminds of The Promised Neverland, although it only takes 1 episode for them to realise what's happening, instead of 3 seasons like in this anime. Although something that bothers me is how blatantly obvious the main characters plot armour is. If you have seen the show you should understand exactly what I mean. So yeah. This show, in my mind, went from somewhat interesting and cool but messy with many loose ends to something that makes perfect sense. Although all is fine now, I still somewhat dislike the previous seasons for not giving more clues. Oh well, nothing is perfect I guess, but this comes really close.

In this season of Attack on... what are we even attacking at that point? Erwin only committed warcrimes for science and the betterment of humanity, Isayama made the Jews from that Austrian guy's best seller into a real thing, Levi throws for content, Armin gets bullied EVEN MORE and Eren has discovered the end goal of gamers all around the world: genocide. This season can be most accurately cut into two parts, or arcs as people with ego problems call them. The first one is about siege warfare, monkeys, child abuse and Erwin's last warcrimes, and the second part is exposition dump, and the least arousing beach ... episode of all times. The siege warfare part is pretty much the thing you'd expect from AoT action, basically blood, death, and naked people. That and a few plot devices that may or may not be exploited further along into the story. And the exposition dump is about putting even more plot on your plot, explaining things I'm probably the only person to care about, more things that I'm probably the only one to not care about. Also Eren is now his own father, so that means he did have sex with someone's mother. As a package content, it was pretty good. I don't see what everyone raves about, to me it looks more like padding for the sake of elongation than it does Isayama's brain being the size of an 8 year old, but AoT's internal politics had me nerding enough to give its future external pokitics a chance. So y'know, time to watch season 4 I guess.

<Potential Spoilers> The episodes that the series has been building up to since episode one. Season three, part two has some moments that the series has been building up to since 2012. To be specific, whatever was in the basement is finally revealed. And to say it was something I didn’t expect would be an understatement. Aside from the basement reveal. Part two has a narrative that concludes the story of titans that we knew before and sets up the final season. The sound design is slightly improved from part one, the return of Wits best animation and some of the best character moments in Attack on ... Titan. In terms of the entire story of Attack on Titan, this small span of episodes is by far the most significant moment in the entire anime. It is the return to Shiganshina, the town destroyed in the first episode of Attack on Titan. The battle against the Colossal and Armoured Titan. We see the original cast work together and fight before we move onto a completely different narrative. While I won’t get into specifics, part two has some of the best moments in the entire series. In a way part two serves as a bridge between the story so far and the conclusion of the story. Part two not only sets up the concluding season, but sets up something that is far bigger then the world within the walls. The world is a lot bigger then we ever thought it would be. Part two answers every question that the series has set up. The sound design has slightly improved from part one of season three. While the voice performances were never bad in part one, or the sound effects. In fact, I’m willing to say the sound effects have always been good. The only problem being the fact that in combat we’ve only ever heard the satisfying sound of ODMG. Never anything else which risks the sound of the ODMG to get annoying. But with addition of thunder spears to the arsenal of our characters. The sound design of fight scenes have a little more variety. The main improvement from part one is the opening, I found red swan to be boring and is only good because of the opening visuals. This new opening is a lot more intense and highlights all the key moments  of the return of Shiganshina. However, the soundtrack hasn’t improved much. While many songs feel like they belong in Attack on Titan, they just don’t match to the soundtrack of season one or two. I can remember being emotionally invested in many key moments of season one and two, mainly because of the soundtrack. I can’t remember any moments like that in season three. It goes without saying that the animators of Wit studio are talented, you can see that talent shine within this part. The animation hits all the bases of good animation perfectly. Solid line work, smooth movement, characters blend into the environment seamlessly, the lighting and colours mix together, and so on. The animators hit all these criteria perfectly and have flawless demonstrations of the basics of good animation. However, the true talent of these animators really shows in the fight scenes. Whether it be the Levi vs beast Titan, the 104th training Corp fighting the colossal titan or the entire survey Corp fighting the armoured titan. All the fight scenes were amazing. Mikasa and Levi’s fast movements in the ODMG was both satisfying and brutal, highlighting how dangerous they truely are. The colossal titans transformation was one of the most shocking moments in the entire arc, and the way it’s animated does this justice. However, the cgi of the colossal titan didn’t work for me. And the anatomy of characters didn’t always remain consistent. At times, Erwins face would look squashed and not right. The series puts its focus on Levi, Erwin and Armin. Erwin represents a character that did everything to achieve his goal, going as far as to sacrifice hundreds of human lives to reach his goal. And even in the end Erwin never really achieves his goal and his efforts were for nothing. Character arcs not properly tied up make me feel true sympathy, because in the real world many people die without doing everything they want. And Erwin to me represents that idea. Levi is given one of the most difficult decisions in the entire series. We’ve always seen Levi act in ways that are either black or white. He does what he needs to do in order to push forward. A trait that isn’t really human. But the moment he has to make the most difficult decision, we see that he can’t just act based on instinct anymore. We can see a rare reveal of a very human character within Levi who feels true emotion. Armin throughout the entire series has demonstrated potential to be an even better commander then Erwin. Which is demonstrated in the training corps fight against the colossal titan. His true intelligence shines in the fight which is what saves the 104. And there are so many more amazing character moments in the series. The cast has many complex and deep personalities that are explored in the series. This second part serves to wrap up character arcs and transition characters to the final season. While this part isn’t without its flaws, season three part two of Attack on Titan is able to conclude the war against titans storyline and simultaneously sets up the final season. All while having good sound effects, the work of talented animators, and the best character moments. Overall, I rank this 8/10.

I knew the big reveal before watching unfortunately, but it still hit like a bag of bricks. What is inside that damn basement, that unlocks the secrets to everything? The main battle this half of a season revolves around is the best battle yet. The stakes are incredibly high and the two sides are very strongly motivated. I like the focus on Erwin, he is a cool character and it's good to see his grit tested in the ultimate battle. Eren, Mikasa and Armin of course carry their weight as well. Such a fantastic battle, excellent animation and storytelling. The Titan battles here are so damn badass, ... it cannot be understated. Because of the aforementioned stakes you are really invested to see them win. The big reveal is absolutely insane. It's a game changer and really really really good. There is cheeky foreshadowing before it, but there are hints throughout the entire show's run about it. So awesome how they reveal it. The brief glimpse of their reactions we get are impactful, particularly the closing scene's iconic image if you know what I mean. It's very good anime. You cannot watch the previous seasons and miss this one, it's the best so far for sure. I love it, a 9/10.

I wasn’t a fan of season 3 part 1 because of the lack of action, but this is completely made up in season 3 part 2! Arguably one of the best arcs is in this season. It’s all you want and more! (spoiler free) Story - 10 So much suspense! Return to Shiganshina is one of my favorite arcs in this entire series! It makes me remember season one, but this time around, the characters have undergone so much and learned so much more about titans that they are like a completely different set of people. It’s so amazing to see how much everyone has grown as ... the fight titans back where it all started. Every part of this season three part two was so fun to watch, there was so much that I didn’t expect would happen. Art - 10 Art is amazing, you already know. Sound - 9 This opening is great but it doesn’t have the same spark for me that all the others do. It just falls short of being top tier like Sasageyo! Characters - 10 YAY! We got some great character development which was seriously lacking in the first part of season three! We got to see the characters we love, like Eren, Mikasa, and Armin! And they were amazing at fighting! I just started to love these characters even more this season. Some of them really showcase their courageousness here! Enjoyment - 10 It just couldn’t get any better than this. It’s the same vibes as season one, which was amazing to watch. The pacing was perfect and I saw all the character I loved, making every minute enjoyable. Overall - 10 I would for sure want to watch season three part two again. This season was filled with so much action as well as some heart wrenching scenes. Perfect! TLDR: Attack on Titan Season 3 Part 2 is back on track with all the suspense and action you got in season 1!

Attack on Titan Season Three, Part Two: This is where I finally felt like I was back in the first season—what an outstanding job Isayama, the animators, and the directors of this third season, second part, have delivered. The farewell to Wit Studio plays a beautiful role in this exceptional anime. Isayama demonstrates complete effectiveness in creating an intense battle, with plot intricacies, mysteries, fights, strategy, and emotions all on full display in his writing prowess. In this section, Isayama proves to be a genius, with every scene and episode showcasing the writer's complete mastery. Tension and movement go hand in hand in a single arc, ... which, in my opinion, is the best one so far. This is where I consider all the elements to be well-executed—all the decisions made by the protagonist, deuteragonist, and antagonists of this arc. Characters showcase their full writing ability, with antagonists exuding charm and delivering a stellar performance. Here, Isayama works at his full capacity, and I believe this segment represents the pinnacle of the entire work. Watching all the twists and turns, both in the battles and in the conclusion of this mystery, is perfect—the soundtrack and animation are impeccable. This is the point where everyone who has watched this far experiences suffering, screams, and cries with a range of emotions, which is not only good but phenomenal! Here's my 10/10.

Attack On Titan, one of the most popular shows to date and has recently ended with a spectacular finale that has a led to a divide in the community. But, that spectacular ending would have been conceived if it weren't for season three of Attack on Titan. It was the perfect season in which all the buildup from previous seasons, the growth of main characters and side characters, the worldbuilding and shocking reveals that flipped the world the characters and viewer once understood upside down, and the overarching plot that showcases a reoccurring theme of hatred. This was truly the perfect season, and is the best ... season of anime to date.

I really like this season of AoT, to the point that I even increased the score of season 1 and season 3 after watching it. I think everything about this show that can be said has been said. Most loved it, some thought it was overrated. Some didnt like it. For me, it changed from a dude who liked the show to a fanboy. This season of AoT is great. It has intense action and drama. The tension is through the roof. There is actual emotions being evoked in every moment the battle takes place. Every time the battle dynamic shifts there is an actual sense ... of victory or dread. Add it with a great reveal and poof you have got a banger. With all that said, this season of AoT does not do anything new. If you are not interested in any of its aspects- the mystery, the characters, the reason why everything became this way, the story or the action, then you are going to think its overrated( a meaningless word imo). Only if you had ANY interest in any of the previous seasons, can this season convert you, as it takes all the great elements of the previous seasons, perfects it, puts it in a 10 episode package and boom, a banger. This is great.

Shingeki no Kyojin, Attack on Titan, whatever you want to call it, is a literal classic in the making. Like every other person on the face of the heart, AOT was my first anime, and I cannot shut up about it. I watched season one back when I was in 4th grade, and the day I was asked to write about my favorite T.V show and character, you know DAMN well I answered AOT and Mikasa. Now was it emotionally scaring to watch that one guy put a gun in his mouth and kill himself in that one episode in season one? Yes. Did I ... continue to watch the show? Yes. What can I say, my badass 10 yr old personality came directly from Mikasa herself. --- Now let's get onto the actual review. I'd like to start off by saying a lot of people think that AOT is overrated, and you know what, to an extent, it kinda is. Now what I mean by this is that seasons 1 and 2 can be considered "overrated" and I would partly agree, but the show was still goddamn amazing. The plot was original, the characters were loveable and different, the show could go from people being eaten alive to potato ( BEST! ) girl flawlessly, and the animation was gorgeous. Don't get me started on the soundtrack and ops cause you already know I loved every second of it. Now I understand how the hype died down for season 2, considering the 4 and a half year wait, but again Season 2 didn't fail to impress me again, with all the stunning characters, visuals, and plot development that we all fell in love with in Season 1. Now we finally arrive at Season 3 ( only took me forever to get here ) but this season, both parts 1 and 2, is what is going to make AOT one of the greatest animes of all time. In Season 3 each character has major development, and you can't argue otherwise. There's no longer just best girl Mikasa, badass Levi, horny-for-titans Hange, and "MAYBE IF I SCREAM ENOUGH THE TITANS WILL FALL TO MY FEET AND I WILL CRUSH THEM WITH MY BARE HANDS I WILL EXTERMINATE THEM FROM THE FACE OF THE EARTH!!" Eren. They become so much more than just these characters playing a role, and they have some of the best character developments I have ever seen. Its no more angsty teen kills mindless titans, as is portrayed in Seasons 1 and 2, but these characters grew up, and we grew up with them. Their morals and beliefs may have changed over the course of the previous seasons, but they stay grounded in their roots, and to see this as a viewer is beyond amazing. The plot just gets better and better as you go, and all the reveals and additions make SENSE. They're not just throwing random things at you left and right, and with a little bit of brain-power, you can easily see that the plot is so much more than is just at the surface. We are introduced to racial discrimination, corrupt government and society blindly supporting it, different cultures and beliefs, and different characters and their response to this flood of new information. These characters realized their just living in a world that is just part of something bigger, and their whole lives and distances has so much more meaning than what they make of it. This isn't just "let's go kill titans" this is something that has evolved past just titans and humans, past humans and humans, this has involved into a show focused on human nature and how people choose to react in a society where nothing is as it seems, nothing is right or wrong, nothing is what they thought it was for decades. This is more than Attack on Titan, this is literally our lives right now. Now with all that said, Season 3 is so so SO deserving of the hype it got in Season 1, and I'm proud of everyone who stuck with the show because it really did pay off. If you dropped AOT after season 1 or 2, KEEP WATCHING. I know the female titan arc wasn't for everyone and trust me I know one signed up for "grwm! forest riding!", but please watch through it because there's so much value in those episodes you thought was annoying, and just because it doesn't make the most sense in the immediate moment doesn't mean that the entire show sucks. I will also like to say that a show not making sense in a moment doesn't make it a bad show at ALL. The animation throughout the entire series remains consistently beautifully, the characters remain amazing, and the plot is something we've never seen before, so if you don't like the show in it's earlier seasons, you never really watched the show. Let it evolve into the show we all love and you'll understand the hype. And finally, if season 4 is executed properly, Shingeki no Kyojin will easily become one of the best animes of all time. I know everyone's not up to date with manga ( which is going fucking WILD rn ) but please wait for season 4 to come out before you make any final decisions about the show. If you're looking for resolves, deeper character development, more fighting and everything else TRUST ME it's coming. In my perspective Season 3 pt 2 had all of those things and more and I absolutely loved every second of it, but if you have doubts about the series, just wait a bit for Season 4 and hopefully, you understand why this show is going to be one of the best shows made in history. Thanks for reading everyone! and goodnight!

After a two year break from Attack on Titan, and after my negative review of the first part of Season 3, I can say that I enjoyed Part 2 much more. Questions are finally being answered. Things are beginning to make sense and tie in with each other. The characters are the same characters we've been with this whole journey. It wasn't as mind-blowing as I remembered the first two seasons, but I enjoyed myself this time around. The pacing is nice, as every decision and thought is nicely detailed and rational. It is also a short 10 episode, making it easy to binge watch. ... I'm curious to see what happens in the final season.

This season of Attack on Titan was tasked with adapting some of the most important material in the entire manga, material that will have large ramifications for the final season coming out next year. Despite having some problems and being inferior to the manga for the most part, this season of AOT did its job well enough, being a suitable supplement for the manga. I wasn’t very impressed by the first four episodes of this season. I’ve never been too fond of the titan fights in this series, so when they also look rather subpar, animation wise, I hardly get anything out of it, but ... thankfully episode five was absolutely spectacular. Arifumi Imai carried this episode with some genuinely incredible animation cuts. Levi vs the Beast Titan, while not being scored very well, looked fantastic. The dynamic camera angles and Imai’s understanding of high speed movement are as present in this fight as they ever have been. My next animation highlight was when Eren took down the Colossal Titan, animated once again, by Imai. The thing that I appreciated the most about this animation cut, was that at the start, as the camera quickly rises, the building in front was traditionally drawn, not a 3D model as is usually the case in Attack on Titan. It added a more elastic feeling to the animation which is something that I greatly appreciate. To discuss the visual direction in this season, it was quite frankly, subpar. Tetsuro Araki’s absence was once again felt in this season. The overwhelming intensity and overall visual flare that he brought to AOT in the first two seasons will probably never return. The great animation was able to cover up for the weak direction in episode five, but most of the other big moments in this season just felt rather flat. The scene between Grisha and the Owl on top of the wall was particularly disappointing. In my head I could picture exactly how Araki would have handled the scene, but what I was seeing on screen was a far cry from what I pictured.
